ADAL.Function: Unknown. However, topological cluster analyses suggest ADA may be involved in chemosensation ([Sohn et al., 2011](http://www.ploscompbiol.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pcbi.1001139)).  &nbsp_place_holder;
ADAL.Location: Lateral in head, at the level of the second bulb of the pharynx
ADAL.Neurotransmitter/Neuropeptide: _**    - Glutamate - Possibly [FLP-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001451), a FMRFamide-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](http://www.wormatlas.org/neurotransmitterstable.htm);[ Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Lee et al.,1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3))

ADAR.Function: Unknown. However, topological cluster analyses suggest ADA may be involved in chemosensation ([Sohn et al., 2011](http://www.ploscompbiol.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pcbi.1001139)).  &nbsp_place_holder;
ADAR.Location: Lateral in head, at the level of the second bulb of the pharynx
ADAR.Neurotransmitter/Neuropeptide: _**    - Glutamate - Possibly [FLP-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001451), a FMRFamide-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](http://www.wormatlas.org/neurotransmitterstable.htm);[ Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Lee et al.,1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3))

ADEL.Description: Anterior deirids. The sensillar branch from the dorsal process follows a dorsal and frequently posterior trajectory ending laterally within the lateral alae in the anterior third of the body. See [Deirids](http://wormatlas.org/hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Anteriorandposteriordeiridsensilla35).
ADEL.Function: _ **   - ADEL/R are dopaminergic **nose touch mechanoceptors.** They modulate locomotion behavior in response to the presence of food by textural mechanosensation, wherein upon encountering a lawn of bacteria (or Sephadex G-200 beads) worms slow their forward movement. The three classes of ciliated dopaminergic neurons ([CEPs](CEPframeset.html), [ADEs](ADEframeset.html), and [PDEs](PDEframeset.html)) function redundantly in this behavior (i.e. sensing the mechanosensory stimuli during crawling through bacteria (or the beads) and communicating with the motor circuit to bring about the locomotory change) ([Sawin et al., 2000](http://www.cell.com/neuron/retrieve/pii/S089662730081199Xr)). Another form of motor plasticity related to food presence is area restricted search (ARS). [CEP](CEPframeset.html) and [PDE](PDEframeset.html) neurons work synergistically to mediate this behavior while ADE modulates it ([Hills et al., 2004](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/24/5/1217.long)). -** Anterior harsh touch sensation:** Laser ablation of [FLP](FLPframeset.html), [AQR](AQRframeset.html), ADE results in a significant reduction of anterior harsh touch sensation, while laser ablation of [BDU](BDUframeset.html), [SDQR](SDQframeset.html), [FLP](FLPframeset.html), ADE and [AQR ](AQRframeset.html) eliminates it ([Li et al., 2011](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/journal/v2/n5/full/ncomms1308.html#/references)). - Possibly **pheromone sensation:** The complete pheromone insensitivity of the _[tax-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006525)(p694)_ mutant suggests that this defect is due to a site of action in one or more of the [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ASE ](ASEframeset.html), ADE, or [BAG](BAGframeset.html) neurons, since the _[tax-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006525)(p694)_ mutation eliminates expression of the [TAX-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/protein/WP:CE17780) subunit from these, but has normal expression and function in the other seven neurons that express this channel ([Aillion and Thomas, 2000](http://www.genetics.org/content/156/3/1047.long)).
ADEL.Location: Lateral in head, behind the second bulb of the pharynx
ADEL.Receptor expression: _**   - [DOP-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001053); dopamine receptor - [EXP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001373); excitatory, cation-selective GABA receptor - [TYRA-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006475); tyramine receptor - Possibly [ACR-16](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00000055); nicotinic acetylcholine receptor ([Altun, 2011](http://www.wormatlas.org/NTRmainframe.htm); [Wragg et al., 2007](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/27/49/13402.long); [Feng et al., 2006](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2859215/?tool=pubmed); [Beg and Jorgensen, 2003](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14555952?dopt=abstract); [Suo et al., 2003](http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi- bin/fulltext/118871307/HTMLSTART))

ADER.Description: Anterior deirids. The sensillar branch from the dorsal process follows a dorsal and frequently posterior trajectory ending laterally within the lateral alae in the anterior third of the body. See [Deirids](http://wormatlas.org/hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Anteriorandposteriordeiridsensilla35).
ADER.Function: _ **   - ADEL/R are dopaminergic **nose touch mechanoceptors.** They modulate locomotion behavior in response to the presence of food by textural mechanosensation, wherein upon encountering a lawn of bacteria (or Sephadex G-200 beads) worms slow their forward movement. The three classes of ciliated dopaminergic neurons ([CEPs](CEPframeset.html), [ADEs](ADEframeset.html), and [PDEs](PDEframeset.html)) function redundantly in this behavior (i.e. sensing the mechanosensory stimuli during crawling through bacteria (or the beads) and communicating with the motor circuit to bring about the locomotory change) ([Sawin et al., 2000](http://www.cell.com/neuron/retrieve/pii/S089662730081199Xr)). [CEP](CEPframeset.html) and [PDE](PDEframeset.html) neurons work synergistically to mediate this behavior while ADE modulates it ([Hills et al., 2004](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/24/5/1217.long)). -** Anterior harsh touch sensation:** Laser ablation of [FLP](FLPframeset.html), [AQR](AQRframeset.html), ADE results in a significant reduction of anterior harsh touch sensation, while laser ablation of [BDU](BDUframeset.html), [SDQR](SDQframeset.html), [FLP](FLPframeset.html), ADE and [AQR ](AQRframeset.html) eliminates it ([Li et al., 2011](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/journal/v2/n5/full/ncomms1308.html#/references)). - Possibly **pheromone sensation:** The complete pheromone insensitivity of the _[tax-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006525)(p694)_ mutant suggests that this defect is due to a site of action in one or more of the [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ASE ](ASEframeset.html), ADE, or [BAG](BAGframeset.html) neurons, since the _[tax-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006525)(p694)_ mutation eliminates expression of the [TAX-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/protein/WP:CE17780) subunit from these, but has normal expression and function in the other seven neurons that express this channel ([Aillion and Thomas, 2000](http://www.genetics.org/content/156/3/1047.long)).
ADER.Location: Lateral in head, behind the second bulb of the pharynx
ADER.Receptor expression: _**   - [DOP-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001053); dopamine receptor - [EXP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001373); excitatory, cation-selective GABA receptor - [TYRA-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006475); tyramine receptor - Possibly [ACR-16](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00000055); nicotinic acetylcholine receptor ([Altun, 2011](http://www.wormatlas.org/NTRmainframe.htm); [Wragg et al., 2007](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/27/49/13402.long); [Feng et al., 2006](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2859215/?tool=pubmed); [Beg and Jorgensen, 2003](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14555952?dopt=abstract); [Suo et al., 2003](http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi- bin/fulltext/118871307/HTMLSTART))

ADFL.Description: [Amphid neurons](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Amphidsensilla31), with [dual (A_d_F) ciliated sensory endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_chemosensation/chemosensation.html#sec1) which are exposed to the external environment. Enter ring via commissure from ventral ganglion. Take up FITC.
ADFL.Function: in the worm and may couple environmental food signals with serotonin neurotransmission ([Jafari et al., 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/24/8948.longr)). - They contribute to a residual **[chemotactic response](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_chemosensation/chemosensation.html)** to cAMP, biotin, Cl-, and Na+ after [ASE](ASEframeset.html) is killed ([Bargmann and Horvitz, 1991](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0896-6273(91)90276-6)). _C. elegans_ shows chemoattraction to low NaCl. This is mediated by four pairs ([ADF](ADFframeset.html), [ASE](ASEframeset.html), [ASG](ASGframeset.html) and [ASI](ASIframeset.html)) of amphid sensory neurons, of which the [ASE](ASEframeset.html) cells are most important. It also shows avoidance of NaCl concentrations above 200 mM which is thought to be due to a general avoidance of high osmotic strength (mainly mediated by the [ASH](ASHframeset.html) sensory neurons). However, this response to salt is plastic, involving a balance between attraction and avoidance, i.e., balances between [ASE](ASEframeset.html), [ASI](ASIframeset.html), [ASH](ASHframeset.html), [ADF](ADFframeset.html) and perhaps [ADL](ADLframeset.html) neuron ([Hukema et al, 2006](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v25/n2/full/7600940a.html)). - **Control entry into dauer stage;** ADF,[ ASI](ASIframeset.html) and [ASG](ASEframeset.html) inhibit entry into dauer stage while [ASJ](ASJframeset.html) and [ASK](ASKframeset.html) promote dauer entry ([Kim et al., 2009](http://www.cell.com/neuron/retrieve/pii/S0896627300802032); [Ouellett et al., 2008](http://dev.biologists.org/content/135/15/2583.long); [Schackwitz et al., 1996](http://www.sciencemag.org/content/326/5955/994.abstract); [Bargmann and Horvitz, 1991](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0896-6273(91)90276-6)). - Function as part of the **oxygen-sensing network** (which also includes [URX](URXframeset.html), [AQR](AQRframeset.html), [PQR](PQRframeset.html), [SDQ](SDQframeset.html), [ALN](ALNframeset.html), [PLN](PLNframeset.html),[ ADL](ADLframeset.html), and [ASH](ASHframeset.html)) by promoting hyperoxia avoidance. ADF pair stimulates aerotaxis in the absence of food by producing serotonin ([Chang et al., 2006](http://www.plosbiology.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.0040274)). -** Modulate NMJ neurotransmission;** serotonin functions as a neuromodulator by inhibiting and enhancing synaptic transmission of other neurotransmitters; e. g. studies have revealed both stimulatory and inhibitory serotonin inputs to the NMJs. Aldicarb, an inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase, causes paralysis in _C. elegans_ due to accumulation of acetylcholine (ACh) at the locomotory NMJs, but exogenous serotonin inhibits paralysis induced by aldicarb. By contrast, exogenous serotonin does not reduce the paralysis induced by levamisole, a specific agonist of the nicotinic ACh receptor[ UNC-29](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/protein/WP:CE13451) in the bodywall muscles. This suggests that serotonin signaling inhibits ACh release by the motor neurons. Studies showed that the inhibitory and stimulatory serotonin signals to NMJ neurotransmission arise from distinct serotonergic neurons; endogenous serotonin released from the ADF neurons stimulates ACh synaptic transmission at the NMJs, whereas serotonin from the [NSM](NSMframeset.html)/[RIH](RIHframeset.html)/[AIM](AIMframeset.html) neurons inhibits the stimulatory serotonin inputs ([Govorunova et al., 2010](http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0010368)).
ADFL.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - [ Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamines/monoamines.html#sec5) - [FLP-6](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001449); FMRFamide-like peptide - [INS-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002084); insulin-like peptide - [NLP-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003741); neuropeptide-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](http://www.wormatlas.org/neurotransmitterstable.htm); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [ Kodama et al., 2006](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/20/21/2955); [ Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long);[ Sze et al., 2000 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003903;class=Paper);[ Duerr et al.,1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/72))
ADFL.Receptor expression: _**   -[ MGL-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00021152); metabotropic glutamate receptor family protein -[ NPR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00021983); receptor for [_flp-18_](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001461) encoded peptides -[ OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003889); TRPV (transient receptor potential channel, vanilloid subfamily; mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel) - [OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003839); TRPV (transient receptor potential channel, vanilloid subfamily; mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel) - [SRB-6](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005071) (faint); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor - [SRD-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005079) (in male); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor ([Altun, 2011](http://www.wormatlas.org/NTRmainframe.htm); [Cohen et al., 2009](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1550413109000412); [Greer et al., 2008](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2556218/?tool=pubmed); [Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper); [Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259); [Troemel et al.,1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper000023 14;class=Paper))

ADF pair stimulates aerotaxis in the absence of food by producing serotonin ([Chang et al., 2006](http://www.plosbiology.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.0040274)). -** Modulate NMJ neurotransmission;** serotonin functions as a neuromodulator by inhibiting and enhancing synaptic transmission of other neurotransmitters; e. g. studies have revealed both stimulatory and inhibitory serotonin inputs to the NMJs. ADFR.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - [ Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamines/monoamines.html#sec5) - [FLP-6](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001449); FMRFamide-like peptide - [INS-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002084); insulin-like peptide - [NLP-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003741); neuropeptide-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](http://www.wormatlas.org/neurotransmitterstable.htm); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [ Kodama et al., 2006](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/20/21/2955); [ Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long);[ Sze et al., 2000 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003903;class=Paper);[ Duerr et al.,1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/72))

ADLL.Description: [Amphid neurons](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Amphidsensilla31), [dual (A_d_L) ciliated sensory endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_chemosensation/chemosensation.html#sec1). Project directly to ring, take up FITC.
ADLL.Function_: **    - [ASH](ASHframeset.html), ADL, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) and [ASE](ASEframeset.html) sensory neurons are responsible for the **detection of certain chemical repellents. **[ASH](ASHframeset.html) plays a major role in this avoidance, whereas ADL, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) and [ASE](ASEframeset.html) play minor roles that are only evident when [ASH](ASHframeset.html) is missing ([de Bono and Maricq, 2005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259); [Hiliard et al., 2002](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982202008138); [Sambongi et al., 1999](http://journals.lww.com/neuroreport/Abstract/1999/03170/Sensing_of_cadmium_and_copper_ions_by_externally.17.aspx); [Bargmann et al., 1990](http://symposium.cshlp.org/content/55/529.extract)). ADL mediate avoidance behavior from heavy metals (Cd++ and Cu++) ([Sambongi et al., 1999](http://journals.lww.com/neuroreport/Abstract/1999/03170/Sensing_of_cadmium_and_copper_ions_by_externally.17.aspx)), odors (e.g. octanol) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0092-8674(95)90162-0)), high osmotic strength and SDS. - [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL are proposed to **mediate social feeding behavior in response to repulsive cues **(e.g. high O2 levels); ablation of [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL abolishes social feeding behavior transforming social animals to solitary feeders; avoidance of high O2 levels that facilitate aggregation is promoted by [OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003839) and [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003889), and the transmembrane protein [ODR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003851), acting in the nociceptive neurons [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL. [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL, in turn, transmit information about aversive stimuli in the environment to a circuit that is responsible for aggregation, rapid locomotion, and food bordering behavior ([Rogers et al., 2006](http://www.cell.com/current-biology/retrieve/pii/S0960982206013169); [de Bono et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01169)). - Balances between at least four sensory cell types, [ASE](ASEframeset.html), [ASI](ASIframeset.html), [ASH](ASHframeset.html), [ADF](ADFframeset.html) and perhaps ADL, **modulate the response to NaCl** ([Hukema et al, 2006](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v25/n2/full/7600940a.html)).
ADLL.Innexin expression: _**   - [INX-18](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002140) - [INX-19](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002141) - [UNC-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006749) ([Altun et al., 2009](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2732576/?tool=pubmed); [Chuang et al., 2007](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867407004515); [Liu et al., 2006](http://www.jbc.org/content/281/12/7881.long))
ADLL.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _ **   - [FLP-4](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001447); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [FLP-21](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001464); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [NLP-7](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003745); neuropeptide-like peptide - [NLP-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003746); neuropeptide-like peptide - [NLP-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003748); neuropeptide-like peptide ([Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Rogers et al., 2003](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/content/full/157/2/219); [Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long))

ADLR.Description: [Amphid neurons](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Amphidsensilla31), [dual (A_d_L) ciliated sensory endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_chemosensation/chemosensation.html#sec1). Project directly to ring, take up FITC.
ADLR.Function_: **    - [ASH](ASHframeset.html), ADL, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) and [ASE](ASEframeset.html) sensory neurons are responsible for the **detection of certain chemical repellents. **[ASH](ASHframeset.html) plays a major role in this avoidance, whereas ADL, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) and [ASE](ASEframeset.html) play minor roles that are only evident when [ASH](ASHframeset.html) is missing ([de Bono and Maricq, 2005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259); [Hiliard et al., 2002](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982202008138); [Sambongi et al., 1999](http://journals.lww.com/neuroreport/Abstract/1999/03170/Sensing_of_cadmium_and_copper_ions_by_externally.17.aspx); [Bargmann et al., 1990](http://symposium.cshlp.org/content/55/529.extract)). ADL mediate avoidance behavior from heavy metals (Cd++ and Cu++) ([Sambongi et al., 1999](http://journals.lww.com/neuroreport/Abstract/1999/03170/Sensing_of_cadmium_and_copper_ions_by_externally.17.aspx)), odors (e.g. octanol) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0092-8674(95)90162-0)), high osmotic strength and SDS. - [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL are proposed to **mediate social feeding behavior in response to repulsive cues **(e.g. high O2 levels); ablation of [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL abolishes social feeding behavior transforming social animals to solitary feeders; avoidance of high O2 levels that facilitate aggregation is promoted by [OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003839) and [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003889), and the transmembrane protein [ODR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003851), acting in the nociceptive neurons [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL. [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and ADL, in turn, transmit information about aversive stimuli in the environment to a circuit that is responsible for aggregation, rapid locomotion, and food bordering behavior ([Rogers et al., 2006](http://www.cell.com/current-biology/retrieve/pii/S0960982206013169); [de Bono et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01169)). - Balances between at least four sensory cell types, [ASE](ASEframeset.html), [ASI](ASIframeset.html), [ASH](ASHframeset.html), [ADF](ADFframeset.html) and perhaps ADL, **modulate the response to NaCl** ([Hukema et al, 2006](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v25/n2/full/7600940a.html)).
ADLR.Innexin expression: _**   - [INX-18](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002140) - [INX-19](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002141) - [UNC-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006749) ([Altun et al., 2009](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2732576/?tool=pubmed); [Chuang et al., 2007](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867407004515); [Liu et al., 2006](http://www.jbc.org/content/281/12/7881.long))
ADLR.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _ **   - [FLP-4](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001447); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [FLP-21](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001464); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [NLP-7](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003745); neuropeptide-like peptide - [NLP-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003746); neuropeptide-like peptide - [NLP-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003748); neuropeptide-like peptide ([Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Rogers et al., 2003](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/content/full/157/2/219); [Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long))
ADLR.Receptor expression: _**    - [GCY-21](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001546); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003889); TRPV (transient receptor potential channel, vanilloid subfamily; mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel)-cation selective - [OCR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003838); TRPV (transient receptor potential channel, vanilloid subfamily; mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel) - [OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003839); TRPV (transient receptor potential channel, vanilloid subfamily; mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel) - [SRB-6](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005071); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor - [SRE-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005149); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor - [SRH-132](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005349); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor - [SRH-220](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005430); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor - [SRI-51](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005563); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor - [SRO-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005641); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor ([Wormbase](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/anatomy_term/WBbt:000399 7#01--10); [Tobin et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0896-6273(02)00757-2); [de Bono et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01169); [Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259); [Troemel et al., 1995](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0092-8674(95)90162-0))

AFDL.Description: [Amphid neurons](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Amphidsensilla31) with [finger-like (A_f_D) ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis/ciliumbiogenesis.html#sec3) embedded in the [amphid sheath cell](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Socketandsheathcells22).
AFDL.Function_: **    - Functions in **thermotaxis:** AFD neurons are the **main thermosensors **in _C. elegans_ and laser ablation of the AFD pair makes most animals athermotactic ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long); [Beverly et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/32/11718.full); [Kuhara et al, 2008](http://www.sciencemag.org/content/320/5877/803.full?sid=f7c6c504-3b52-4ef9-8681-be6282978c3a); [Satterlee et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960982203009503); [Mori and Ohshima, 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v376/n6538/abs/376344a0.html)). After cultivation at a uniform temperature (Tc) with sufficient food, animals preferentially migrate to their cultivation temperature (Tc) when placed on a thermal gradient, and move isothermally at this temperature ([Hedgecock and Russell 1975](http://www.pnas.org/content/72/10/4061.abstract?ijkey=acd1f08536e1e2ccecf26dc714d2cc0ed9707751&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)). Animals sense and record their Tc by [AFD](AFDframeset.html) (major thermosensory), AWC and ASI neurons ([Beverly et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/32/11718.full); [Kuhara et al., 2008](http://www.sciencemag.org/content/320/5877/803); [Biron et al., 2008](http://www.pnas.org/content/105/31/11002.full)). This memory is plastic and can be reset upon cultivation at a different temperature ([Hedgecock and Russell 1975](http://www.pnas.org/content/72/10/4061.abstract?ijkey=acd1f08536e1e2ccecf26dc714d2cc0ed9707751&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)). The AFD, AWC and ASI neurons may to act in concert to increase turning rate when animals encounter higher temperatures than Tc on a gradient to move down the gradient toward colder temperatures near Tc (negative thermotaxis) ([Biron et al., 2008](http://www.pnas.org/content/105/31/11002.full)). To track isotherms, animals do not actively pursue isothermal alignment, but once serendipitously aligned along an isotherm (at T=Tc), they track by suppressing turns ([Luo et al., 2006](http://jeb.biologists.org/content/209/23/4652.abstract?ijkey=633724e8b725756ac9b884de520177117034b20d&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)).This may be achieved by the animal increasing its reversal frequency when it detects a rise in temperature, which activates Ca++ influx in AFD via cGMP-dependent TAX-2/TAX-4 cation channel (cGMP production in AFD is redundantly carried out by GCY-8, GCY-18 and GCY-23 and _[gcy-23](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001548), [gcy-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001543)_, and _[gcy-18 ](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001543)_triple mutants show a cryophilic or athermotactic phenotype) ([Inada et al., 2006](http://www.genetics.org/content/172/4/2239)). AFD neurons respond to thermal stimuli above Tc with continuous, graded calcium signals in a deterministic and highly reproducible way. The thermal information is transmitted by AFD and AWC to AIY interneurons for information processing, and AIY neurons, in turn, transmit it to AIZ and RIA interneurons for further processing. It is suggested that activation of AFD neurons by warming above Tc induces the animal to reverse by inhibiting AIY since loss of AFD (by ablation) suppresses spontaneous reversals in an AIY-dependent manner, while loss of AIY (by ablation) increases spontaneous reversals ([de Bono and Maricq 2005](http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259); [Tsalik and Hobert, 2003](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/neu.10245/abstract;jsessionid=D8214EBC383488E3FCCD265C4AF8AB47)). - Functions in **locomotion:** Laser ablations of AFD cause hyporeversal phenotype ([Tsalik and Hobert, 2003](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/neu.10245/abstract;jsessionid=D8214EBC383488E3FCCD265C4AF8AB47)). - AFD, [BAG](BAGframeset.html) and [ASE](ASEframeset.html) are primary **CO2 sensors:** AFD and [BAG](BAGframeset.html) neurons together stimulate turning when CO2&nbsp_place_holder;rises and inhibit turning when CO2 falls ([Bretscher et al., 2011](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0896627311001218)). - May be involved in **social feeding **since disruption of [_tax-2_](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006525) expression in AFD, [AQR](AQRframeset.html), [ASE](ASEframeset.html) and [BAG](BAGframeset.html) neurons disrupts social feeding ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v419/n6910/full/nature01170.html)).
AFDL.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - Glutamate - [FLP-6](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001449); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [NLP-7](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003745); neuropeptide-like peptide - [NLP-21](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003759); neuropeptide-like peptide ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B9); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Rogers et al., 2003](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/content/full/157/2/219); [Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long))
AFDL.Receptor expression: _**    - [GCY-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001535); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [GCY-18](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001535); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [GCY-23](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001535); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [GCY-29](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001535); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase ([Wormbase](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/anatomy_term/WBbt:000399 7#01--10); [Ortiz et al., 2006](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC14 61427);[](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC20379/?tool=pubmed)[ Inada et al., 2006](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1456394);[](ht tp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1461427) [ Yu et al., 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC20379/?tool=pubmed))

After cultivation at a uniform temperature (Tc) with sufficient food, animals preferentially migrate to their cultivation temperature (Tc) when placed on a thermal gradient, and move isothermally at this temperature ([Hedgecock and Russell 1975](http://www.pnas.org/content/72/10/4061.abstract?ijkey=acd1f08536e1e2ccecf26dc714d2cc0ed9707751&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)). Animals sense and record their Tc by [AFD](AFDframeset.html) (major thermosensory), AWC and ASI neurons ([Beverly et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/32/11718.full); [Kuhara et al., 2008](http://www.sciencemag.org/content/320/5877/803); [Biron et al., 2008](http://www.pnas.org/content/105/31/11002.full)). This memory is plastic and can be reset upon cultivation at a different temperature ([Hedgecock and Russell 1975](http://www.pnas.org/content/72/10/4061.abstract?ijkey=acd1f08536e1e2ccecf26dc714d2cc0ed9707751&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)). To track isotherms, animals do not actively pursue isothermal alignment, but once serendipitously aligned along an isotherm (at T=Tc), they track by suppressing turns ([Luo et al., 2006](http://jeb.biologists.org/content/209/23/4652.abstract?ijkey=633724e8b725756ac9b884de520177117034b20d&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)).This may be achieved by the animal increasing its reversal frequency when it detects a rise in temperature, which activates Ca++ influx in AFD via cGMP-dependent TAX-2/TAX-4 cation channel (cGMP production in AFD is redundantly carried out by GCY-8, GCY-18 and GCY-23 and _[gcy-23](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001548), [gcy-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001543)_, and _[gcy-18 ](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001543)_triple mutants show a cryophilic or athermotactic phenotype) ([Inada et al., 2006](http://www.genetics.org/content/172/4/2239)). AFD neurons respond to thermal stimuli above Tc with continuous, graded calcium signals in a deterministic and highly reproducible way. The thermal information is transmitted by AFD and AWC to AIY interneurons for information processing, and AIY neurons, in turn, transmit it to AIZ and RIA interneurons for further processing. AIAL.Description: Ring interneurons. AIAL and AIAR are located anteriorly to the excretory cell, at the ventral side of the terminal bulb of pharynx. They are seen very close to each other on the right and left sides of the A-P midline in lateral view.
AIAL.Function_: Integration of information from amphid sensory neurons; AIAL/R is one of the four first layer amphid interneuron pairs (AIA, [AIB](AIBframeset.html), [AIY](AIYframeset.html), and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html)) that receives and processes synaptic output from the amphid sensory neurons towards a behavioral response. AIA pair is suggested to sum inputs from various chemosensory neurons before passing the information on to [AIB](AIBframeset.html) pair, which synapses onto motor neurons (AIA-[AIB](AIBframeset.html) connections are likely to be inhibitory) ([Wakayabashi et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403)). AIA is the main target of ASI outputs. - AIA interneurons integrate multiple sensory cues to adjust behavioral choices and play an important role in **learning** (e.g. salt chemotaxis learning) and **behavioral plasticity **([Shinkai et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/8/3007.long); [Tomioka et al., 2006](http://www.cell.com/neuron/retrieve/pii/S0896627306005897)). - Functions in **locomotion:** in isothermal tracking, [AIB](AIBframeset.html) and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html) interneurons promote turns while [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIA interneurons inhibit turns ([Garrity et al., 2010](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/24/21/2365.long)). - The AIA neurons are required for **chemotaxis** to indole ascarosides, downstream of the [ASK](ASKframeset.html) sensory neuron ([Macosko et al., 2009](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v458/n7242/full/nature07886.html)).
AIAL.Innexin expression: _**   None yet reported, although described to have gap junctions in adult animals ([MoW](../../ver1/MoW_built0.92/toc.html))
AIAL.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - [Acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) - [FLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001444); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [FLP-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001445); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [INS-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002084); insulin-like peptide. Important in the neuropeptide feedback loop between [AWC](AWCframeset.html) and AIA. ([Chalasani et al., 2010](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v13/n5/full/nn.2526.html); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Altun-Gultekin et al., 2001](http://dev.biologists.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/1951); [Nelson et al., 1998](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0169-328X(98)00106-5))
AIAL.Receptor expression: _**    - [GLR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001613)[](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001535); AMPA-type ionotropic (Na+/K+) glutamate receptor subunit  - [GLC-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593)[](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593); L-glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit (ionotropic glutamate rec subunit). AWC-AIA synapse is an inhibitory, glutamatergic synapse via [GLC-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593), whose function is acutely modulated by [NLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003739)/[NPR-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00016110) signaling - [GCY-28](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00020131); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [MGL-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003232); group II metabotropic glutamate receptor -[ NPR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00021983); receptor for [FLP-18](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001461) peptides - [ NPR-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00016110); candidate receptor for[ NLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003739) - [SCD-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00004740); ALK receptor tyrosine kinase - [SRA-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005037); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor ([Wormbase](http://www.wormbase.org);[ Shinkai et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/8/3007.long); [Chalasani et al., 2010](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v13/n5/full/nn.2526.html);[ Glauser and Goodman, 2010](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v13/n5/full/nn0510-528. html#/references); [Greer et al, 2008](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2556218/); [ Altun-Gultekin et al., 2001](http://dev.biologists.org/content/128/11/1951.long);[ Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/21/5/1510.long))

AIAR.Description: Ring interneurons. AIAL and AIAR are located anteriorly to the excretory cell, at the ventral side of the terminal bulb of pharynx. They are seen very close to each other on the right and left sides of the A-P midline in lateral view.
AIAR.Function_: Integration of information from amphid sensory neurons; AIAL/R is one of the four first layer amphid interneuron pairs (AIA, [AIB](AIBframeset.html), [AIY](AIYframeset.html), and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html)) that receives and processes synaptic output from the amphid sensory neurons towards a behavioral response. AIA pair is suggested to sum inputs from various chemosensory neurons before passing the information on to [AIB](AIBframeset.html) pair, which synapses onto motor neurons (AIA-[AIB](AIBframeset.html) connections are likely to be inhibitory) ([Wakayabashi et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403)). AIA is the main target of ASI outputs. - AIA interneurons integrate multiple sensory cues to adjust behavioral choices and play an important role in **learning** (e.g. salt chemotaxis learning) and **behavioral plasticity **([Shinkai et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/8/3007.long); [Tomioka et al., 2006](http://www.cell.com/neuron/retrieve/pii/S0896627306005897)). - Functions in **locomotion:** in isothermal tracking, [AIB](AIBframeset.html) and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html) interneurons promote turns while [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIA interneurons inhibit turns ([Garrity et al., 2010](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/24/21/2365.long)). - The AIA neurons are required for **chemotaxis** to indole ascarosides, downstream of the [ASK](ASKframeset.html) sensory neuron ([Macosko et al., 2009](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v458/n7242/full/nature07886.html)).
AIAR.Innexin expression: _**   None yet reported, although described to have gap junctions in adult animals ([MoW](../../ver1/MoW_built0.92/toc.html))
AIAR.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - [Acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) - [FLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001444); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [FLP-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001445); FMRFamide-like neuropeptide - [INS-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002084); insulin-like peptide. Important in the neuropeptide feedback loop between [AWC](AWCframeset.html) and AIA. ([Chalasani et al., 2010](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v13/n5/full/nn.2526.html); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Altun-Gultekin et al., 2001](http://dev.biologists.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/1951); [Nelson et al., 1998](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0169-328X(98)00106-5))
AIAR.Receptor expression: _**    - [GLR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001613)[](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001535); AMPA-type ionotropic (Na+/K+) glutamate receptor subunit  - [GLC-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593)[](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593); L-glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit (ionotropic glutamate rec subunit). AWC-AIA synapse is an inhibitory, glutamatergic synapse via [GLC-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593), whose function is acutely modulated by [NLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003739)/[NPR-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00016110) signaling - [GCY-28](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00020131); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [MGL-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003232); group II metabotropic glutamate receptor -[ NPR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00021983); receptor for [FLP-18](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001461) peptides - [ NPR-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00016110); candidate receptor for[ NLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003739) - [SCD-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00004740); ALK receptor tyrosine kinase - [SRA-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005037); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor ([Wormbase](http://www.wormbase.org);[ Shinkai et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/8/3007.long); [Chalasani et al., 2010](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v13/n5/full/nn.2526.html);[ Glauser and Goodman, 2010](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v13/n5/full/nn0510-528. html#/references); [Greer et al, 2008](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2556218/); [ Altun-Gultekin et al., 2001](http://dev.biologists.org/content/128/11/1951.long);[ Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/21/5/1510.long))

AIBL.Function: Integration of information from amphid sensory neurons; AIBL/R is one of the four first layer amphid interneuron pairs ([AIA](AIAframeset.html), AIB, [AIY](AIYframeset.html), and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html)) that receives and processes synaptic output from the amphid sensory neurons. [AIA](AIAframeset.html) pair is suggested to sum inputs from various chemosensory neurons before passing the information on to AIB pair, which synapses onto motor neurons ([AIA](AIAframeset.html)-AIB connections are likely to be inhibitory) ([Wakayabashi et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403)). - Functions in **locomotion:** Among the interneurons, AIA and AIY inhibit turns, AIB and AIZ promote turns, and ablation of RIA does not affect turning rates ([Garrity et al., 2010](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/24/21/2365.long); [Wakayabashi et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403)). - Functions in information processing within the [AWC](AWCframeset.html)-AIB-[AIY](AIYframeset.html) circuit that controls **food- and odor-evoked behaviors** ([Chalasani et al., 2007](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v450/n7166/full/nature06292.html)). After animals are removed from bacterial food, they initiate a **local search behavior** consisting of reversals and deep omega-shaped turns. This is followed by dispersal ~30 min later, as reversals and turns are suppressed. Local search behavior is triggered by AWC olfactory neurons, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) gustatory neurons, and AIB interneurons while dispersal is promoted by [ASI](ASIframeset.html) gustatory neurons and [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons ([Gray et al., 2005](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long)). [AWC](AWCframeset.html) neurons are activated by odor removal and activate the AIB interneurons through AMPA-type glutamate receptors, while they inhibit [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons through glutamate-gated chloride channels; odor presentation relieves this inhibition and results in activation of [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons. The opposite regulation of [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIB interneurons generates a coordinated behavioral response. - **Regulates lifespan **and ** starvation response** (starvation induces heat-shock resistance, oxidative stress resistance and extension of life-span). Certain amino acids (such as leu, gln, ala, val, ile) might act as signaling molecules that modulate the starvation response by acting as anti-hunger signals. The amino acid signal activates [AIY](AIYframeset.html) neurons and inhibits AIB neurons by modulating the activities of [MGL-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003232) and [MGL-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003233) metabotropic glutamate receptors, respectively. [AIY](AIYframeset.html) then inhibits the starvation response, whereas AIB activates it ([Shen et al, 2010](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047637410001958);[ Kang and Avery, 2009](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/23/1/12.long)).
AIBL.Receptor expression: _**   - [GLR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001612); glutamate-activated cation channel - [GLR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001613); glutamate-activated cation channel - Possibly [GLR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001616); kainate (non-NMDA)-type ionotropic glutamate receptor - Possibly [GGR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001586); GABA-A/glycine receptor-like protein - Possibly [MGL-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003233); metabotropic glutamate receptor ([Fujiwara et al., 1996](http://www.wormbook.org/wli/wbg14.4p69/); [Maricq et al., 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v378/n6552/abs/378078a0.html); [Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510);[ Kang and Avery, 2009](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/23/1/12.long))

AIBR.Function: Integration of information from amphid sensory neurons; AIBL/R is one of the four first layer amphid interneuron pairs ([AIA](AIAframeset.html), AIB, [AIY](AIYframeset.html), and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html)) that receives and processes synaptic output from the amphid sensory neurons. [AIA](AIAframeset.html) pair is suggested to sum inputs from various chemosensory neurons before passing the information on to AIB pair, which synapses onto motor neurons ([AIA](AIAframeset.html)-AIB connections are likely to be inhibitory) ([Wakayabashi et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403)). - Functions in **locomotion:** Among the interneurons, AIA and AIY inhibit turns, AIB and AIZ promote turns, and ablation of RIA does not affect turning rates ([Garrity et al., 2010](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/24/21/2365.long); [Wakayabashi et al., 2004](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403)). - Functions in information processing within the [AWC](AWCframeset.html)-AIB-[AIY](AIYframeset.html) circuit that controls **food- and odor-evoked behaviors** ([Chalasani et al., 2007](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v450/n7166/full/nature06292.html)). After animals are removed from bacterial food, they initiate a **local search behavior** consisting of reversals and deep omega-shaped turns. This is followed by dispersal ~30 min later, as reversals and turns are suppressed. Local search behavior is triggered by AWC olfactory neurons, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) gustatory neurons, and AIB interneurons while dispersal is promoted by [ASI](ASIframeset.html) gustatory neurons and [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons ([Gray et al., 2005](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long)). [AWC](AWCframeset.html) neurons are activated by odor removal and activate the AIB interneurons through AMPA-type glutamate receptors, while they inhibit [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons through glutamate-gated chloride channels; odor presentation relieves this inhibition and results in activation of [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons. The opposite regulation of [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIB interneurons generates a coordinated behavioral response. - **Regulates lifespan **and ** starvation response** (starvation induces heat-shock resistance, oxidative stress resistance and extension of life-span). Certain amino acids (such as leu, gln, ala, val, ile) might act as signaling molecules that modulate the starvation response by acting as anti-hunger signals. The amino acid signal activates [AIY](AIYframeset.html) neurons and inhibits AIB neurons by modulating the activities of [MGL-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003232) and [MGL-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003233) metabotropic glutamate receptors, respectively. [AIY](AIYframeset.html) then inhibits the starvation response, whereas AIB activates it ([Shen et al, 2010](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047637410001958);[ Kang and Avery, 2009](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/23/1/12.long)).
AIBR.Receptor expression: _**   - [GLR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001612); glutamate-activated cation channel - [GLR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001613); glutamate-activated cation channel - Possibly [GLR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001616); kainate (non-NMDA)-type ionotropic glutamate receptor - Possibly [GGR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001586); GABA-A/glycine receptor-like protein - Possibly [MGL-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003233); metabotropic glutamate receptor ([Fujiwara et al., 1996](http://www.wormbook.org/wli/wbg14.4p69/); [Maricq et al., 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v378/n6552/abs/378078a0.html); [Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510);[ Kang and Avery, 2009](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/23/1/12.long))

AIML.Description: Ring interneurons bridging between sensory inputs and command outputs. Excessive neurites that connect AIML and AIMR early in development are pruned during larval stages (along with [RIF](RIFframeset.html), they are the only other neuron pair that is subject to developmental neurite pruning in _C. elegans_) ([Hayashi et al., 2009](http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v12/n8/full/nn.2347.html); [Kage et al., 2005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2005.07.057)).
AIML.Function: Serotonin secreted by both synaptic vesicles and dense core vesicles seem to diffuse readily to the extrasynaptic space adjacent to the AIM and [RIH](RIHframeset.html) neurons. Among 5 classes ([NSM](NSMframeset.html), [ADF](ADFframeset.html), [HSN](HSNframeset.html), AIM, [RIH](RIHframeset.html)) of serotonergic neurons, [RIH](RIHframeset.html) and AIM mainly take up serotonin from outside -produced by the remaining serotonergic neurons- via the membrane serotonin transporter ([MOD-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/protein/WP:CE28995)/SERT), rather than synthesizing it themselves ([Jafari et al., 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/24/8948.long)). -[ RIH](RIHframeset.html) and AIM possibly function as ** temporal-spatial regulators of extrasynaptic serotonin **to modulate the activity of the behavioral circuits. In _Caenorhabditis elegans_, serotonin signaling is required for coupling feeding and the memory of prior food availability to the rate of locomotion. Following food deprivation, wild-type animals show markedly decreased locomotion on their return to a lawn of bacterial food. While serotonin-deficient mutants exhibit less slowing response (become insensitive), mutants of _[mod-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003387)_/SERT exaggerate the slowing response (become hypersensitive). Transgenic expression of_[ mod-5](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003387)_/SERT in the serotonin-absorbing neurons fully corrects this exaggerated behavior, suggesting AIM and [RIH](RIHframeset.html) regulate the availability of serotonin for neurotransmission ([Jafari et al., 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/24/8948.long)). - Functions in **swim initiation;** Behaviorally, ablation of [VC-4](VCNframeset.html), [VC-5](VCNframeset.html), AIM, or [NSM](NSMframeset.html) neurons delays swim onset, implicating serotonin signaling in this behavior ([Vidal-Gadea et al., 2011](http://www.pnas.org/content/108/42/17504.long)).
AIML.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _ **   - [Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamines/monoamines.html#sec5) - [FLP-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001453); FMRFamide-like peptide - [FLP-22](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00009562); FMRFamide-like peptide - [INS-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002084); insulin-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](../../neurotransmitterstable.htm); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html);[ Sze et al., 2000](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v403/n6769/full/403560a0.html); [Duerr et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/72))

AIMR.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _ **   - [Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamines/monoamines.html#sec5) - [FLP-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001453); FMRFamide-like peptide - [FLP-22](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00009562); FMRFamide-like peptide - [INS-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002084); insulin-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](../../neurotransmitterstable.htm); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html);[ Sze et al., 2000](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v403/n6769/full/403560a0.html); [Duerr et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/72))

AINL.Function: AIN is presynaptic to [AFD](AFDframeset.html), however, the significance of this connection is not yet clear.
AINL._Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - Possibly [glutamate](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) (the neuron may be [AVJ](AVJframeset.html) instead) - [FLP-19](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001462); FMRFamide-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](../../neurotransmitterstable.htm); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Lee et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3))

AINR.Function: AIN is presynaptic to [AFD](AFDframeset.html), however, the significance of this connection is not yet clear.
AINR._Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - Possibly [glutamate](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) (the neuron may be [AVJ](AVJframeset.html) instead) - [FLP-19](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001462); FMRFamide-like peptide ([Loer, 2010](../../neurotransmitterstable.htm); [Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html); [Lee et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3))

AIYL.Function: AIY neurons are postsynaptic to several olfactory and gustatory sensory neurons, such as ASE, ASI, AWA, AWC and AFD, and are presumed to play an integrative role, processing multiple streams of sensory information. They have a key role in behavioral plasticity in paradigms in which starvation is paired with a thermal or chemical cue ([de Bono and Maricq, 2005](http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259?url_ver=Z39.88-2003&rfr_id=ori:rid:crossref.org&rfr_dat=cr_pub%3dpubmed&); [Ishihara et al., 2002](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867402007481)). - Functions in **thermotaxis; **laser ablation of the AIY pair makes the animals cryophilic and impaired in isothermal tracking ([Mori and Ohshima, 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v376/n6538/abs/376344a0.html)). The thermal information sensed by [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ AWC](AWCframeset.html) and [ASI](ASIframeset.html) is processed in downstream interneurons AIY, [AIZ](AIZframeset.html), [RIA](RIAframeset.html), and also likely in AIA and AIB (the first three are considered as thermotaxis core interneurons) ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long); [Sasakura and Mori, 2012](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S095943881200147X);[ Ardiel and Rankin, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201171a.html); [Beverly et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/32/11718.full)). The activation of AIY neuron-signaling drive warm-seeking (thermophilic) movement, the activation of [AIZ](AIZframeset.html) neuron-signaling drive cold-seeking (cryophilic) movement, while the counterbalancing between the AIY and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html) signals through the [RIA](RIAframeset.html) interneuron leads to execution of motor output in response to thermal signals ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html); [Kuhara et al, 2008](http://www.sciencemag.org/content/320/5877/803.full?sid=f7c6c504-3b52-4ef9-8681-be6282978c3a)). AIY is the major postsynaptic partner of AWC and AFD. [AWC](AWCframeset.html)-derived glutamatergic signals stimulate AIY and induce migration to warmer temperature ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html)). AFD transmits both inhibitory and stimulatory signals to AIY such that calcium concentration threshold in AFD acts as a switch for opposing neural signals to AIY that direct opposite (warm- or cold-seeking) behaviors ([Kuhara et al., 2011](http://www.nature.com/ncomms/journal/v2/n6/full/ncomms1352.html)). [AFD](AFDframeset.html)-derived glutamatergic signals inhibit AIY through activation of [GLC-3](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001593) glutamate-gated chloride channel and drive migration towards colder temperature. Recent studies suggest this [AFD](AFDframeset.html) / AIY synapse may have evolved for reliable transmission of a scaled-down temperature signal from [AFD](AFDframeset.html), enabling AIY to monitor and integrate temperature with other sensory inputs ([Narayan et al, 2011](http://www.pnas.org/content/108/23/9667.long)). The molecular mechanism of the stimulatory signaling between AFD and AIY is currently unknown. - Functions in **locomotion:** Suppresses turns and reversals enhancing smooth forward movements and dispersal, since laser ablation of AIY increases reversals and turns, disrupts dispersal behavior and shortens forward movements ([Gray et al., 2005](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long); [Wakayabashi et al., 2004 ](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204001403); [Tsalik and Hobert, 2003](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/neu.10245/abstract;jsessionid=D8214EBC383488E3FCCD265C4AF8AB47)[](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long)). Similar to AIY, laser ablations of ASE or AIA increases the frequency of reversals while ablations of AWC, AIB or AIZ decreases the frequency of reversals (ablations of RIA does not affect turning rates). Since ablations of AIY and [AIZ](AIZframeset.html) (the major postsynaptic partner of AIY) cause opposite behavioral phenotpes, the synapses made by AIY onto AIZ may be inhibitory. Alternatively, signals fom AIY to[ AIZ](AIZframeset.html) are processed in a downstream neuron such as [RIA](RIAframeset.html) ([de Bono and Maricq 2005](http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259)). - Functions in information processing within the [AWC](AWCframeset.html)-[AIB](AIBframeset.html)-AIY circuit that controls **food- and odor-evoked behaviors** ([Chalasani et al., 2007](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v450/n7166/full/nature06292.html)). AWC neurons are activated by food or odor removal and activate the AIB interneurons through AMPA-type glutamate receptors, while they inhibit AIY interneurons through glutamate-gated chloride channels; odor presentation relieves this inhibition and results in activation of AIY interneurons. The opposite regulation of AIY and AIB interneurons generates a coordinated behavioral response. - **Regulates lifespan **and ** starvation response** (starvation induces heat-shock resistance, oxidative stress resistance and extension of life-span). Certain amino acids (such as leu, gln, ala, val, ile) might act as signaling molecules that modulate the starvation response by acting as anti-hunger signals. The amino acid signal activates AIY neurons and inhibits [AIB](AIBframeset.html) neurons by modulating the activities of [MGL-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003232) and [MGL-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003233) metabotropic glutamate receptors in these neurons, respectively. AIY then inhibits the starvation response, whereas [AIB](AIBframeset.html) activates it ([Shen et al, 2010](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047637410001958);[ Kang and Avery, 2009](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/23/1/12.long)).

AIZL.Function: Integration of information from amphid sensory neurons; AIZL/R is one of the four first layer amphid interneuron pairs ([AIA](AIAframeset.html), [AIB](AIBframeset.html), [AIY](AIYframeset.html), and AIZ) that receive and process synaptic output from the amphid sensory neurons towards a behavioral response. Along with the second layer [RIA](RIAframeset.html) and [RIB](RIBframeset.html) interneurons, AIZ also receives heavy input from the first layer [AIA](AIAframeset.html), [AIB](AIBframeset.html), [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons and itself sends inputs to [RIA](RIAframeset.html) and [RIB](RIBframeset.html)[](RIVframeset.html). Additionally, it synapses directly onto [SMB ](SMBframeset.html)head motor neurons . - Functions in **thermotaxis; **laser ablation of the AIZ pair makes the animals thermophilic ([Mori and Ohshima, 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v376/n6538/abs/376344a0.html)). The thermal information sensed by [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ AWC](AWCframeset.html) and [ASI](ASIframeset.html) is processed in downstream interneurons [AIY](AIYframeset.html), AIZ, [RIA](RIAframeset.html), and also likely in [AIA](AIAframeset.html) and [AIB ](AIBframeset.html)(the first three are considered as thermotaxis core interneurons) ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long); [Sasakura and Mori, 2012](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S095943881200147X);[ Ardiel and Rankin, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201171a.html); [Beverly et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/32/11718.full)). In the original two-drive model of thermotaxis, activation of AIY neuron-signaling drive warm-seeking (thermophilic) movement, activation of AIZ neuron-signaling drive cold-seeking (cryophilic) movement, while the counterbalancing between the [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIZ signals possibly through the [RIA](RIAframeset.html) interneuron leads to execution of motor output in response to thermal signals ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html); [Kuhara et al, 2008](http://www.sciencemag.org.elibrary.einstein.yu.edu/content/320/5877/803.full?sid=f7c6c504-3b52-4ef9-8681-be6282978c3a)). However, there is evidence that a thermophilic drive at temperatures below cultivation temperature (Tc) does not exist and regulation of thermotaxis involves a more complex circuit ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long); [Ryu and Samuel, 2002](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/22/13/5727.abstract?ijkey=7299ff1afe1cd18b372e1cc786ac1f6a909a6a4b&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)). Around Tc animals track isothermally on a gradient and above Tc they display negative thermotaxis by regulating their turning frequency and  run duration. It has been suggested that thermosensory signals from [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ AWC](AWCframeset.html) and [ASI](ASIframeset.html) converge on the [AIB](AIBframeset.html) interneuron in negative thermotaxis, whereas the [AIY](AIYframeset.html)/AIZ/[RIA](RIAframeset.html) network may function mainly in isothermal tracking ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long)). During associative learning between temperature and feeding state, starvation, a conditioning factor, downregulates AIZ activity through [calcineurin/TAX-6]( http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006527), a calcium- activated phosphatase, leading to avoidance from Tc ([Kuhara and Mori, 2006](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/26/37/9355.long)).  - Functions in **locomotion:** Laser ablations of AIZ, like AIB and AWC, cause decrease in reversals and lead to large increases in the duration of forward movement ([Tsalik and Hobert, 2003](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/neu.10245/abstract;jsessionid=D8214EBC383488E3FCCD265C4AF8AB47); Iino and Yoshida, 2009). Since ablations of [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIZ cause opposite behavioral phenotpes, the synapses made by [AIY](AIYframeset.html) onto AIZ may be inhibitory. Alternatively, signals fom [AIY](AIYframeset.html) to AIZ could be processed in a downstream neuron such as [RIA](RIAframeset.html) ([de Bono and Maricq 2005](http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259)). - Functions in **chemotaxis:** Laser ablations of AIZ cause defects in the weathervane (slow turning of the animal by biased head swing) and pirouette (bout of sharp turns generated by frequent reversals followed by omega turns) responses (see [Nervous System-General Description](../../hermaphrodite/nervous/Neuroframeset.html)) leading to impaired chemotaxis ([Iino and Yoshida, 2009](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/29/17/5370.full#F1)).
AIZL.Receptor expression: ](http](http //www.wormatlas.org/NTRmainframe.htm)_**   - [SER-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00004777); tyramine receptor (expresses two separate splice variants) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0012-1606(03)00447-0))

AIZR.Function: Integration of information from amphid sensory neurons; AIZL/R is one of the four first layer amphid interneuron pairs ([AIA](AIAframeset.html), [AIB](AIBframeset.html), [AIY](AIYframeset.html), and AIZ) that receive and process synaptic output from the amphid sensory neurons towards a behavioral response. Along with the second layer [RIA](RIAframeset.html) and [RIB](RIBframeset.html) interneurons, AIZ also receives heavy input from the first layer [AIA](AIAframeset.html), [AIB](AIBframeset.html), [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons and itself sends inputs to [RIA](RIAframeset.html) and [RIB](RIBframeset.html)[](RIVframeset.html). Additionally, it synapses directly onto [SMB ](SMBframeset.html)head motor neurons . - Functions in **thermotaxis; **laser ablation of the AIZ pair makes the animals thermophilic ([Mori and Ohshima, 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v376/n6538/abs/376344a0.html)). The thermal information sensed by [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ AWC](AWCframeset.html) and [ASI](ASIframeset.html) is processed in downstream interneurons [AIY](AIYframeset.html), AIZ, [RIA](RIAframeset.html), and also likely in [AIA](AIAframeset.html) and [AIB ](AIBframeset.html)(the first three are considered as thermotaxis core interneurons) ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long); [Sasakura and Mori, 2012](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S095943881200147X);[ Ardiel and Rankin, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201171a.html); [Beverly et al, 2011](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/31/32/11718.full)). In the original two-drive model of thermotaxis, activation of AIY neuron-signaling drive warm-seeking (thermophilic) movement, activation of AIZ neuron-signaling drive cold-seeking (cryophilic) movement, while the counterbalancing between the [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIZ signals possibly through the [RIA](RIAframeset.html) interneuron leads to execution of motor output in response to thermal signals ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html); [Kuhara et al, 2008](http://www.sciencemag.org.elibrary.einstein.yu.edu/content/320/5877/803.full?sid=f7c6c504-3b52-4ef9-8681-be6282978c3a)). However, there is evidence that a thermophilic drive at temperatures below cultivation temperature (Tc) does not exist and regulation of thermotaxis involves a more complex circuit ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long); [Ryu and Samuel, 2002](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/22/13/5727.abstract?ijkey=7299ff1afe1cd18b372e1cc786ac1f6a909a6a4b&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha)). Around Tc animals track isothermally on a gradient and above Tc they display negative thermotaxis by regulating their turning frequency and  run duration. It has been suggested that thermosensory signals from [AFD](AFDframeset.html), [ AWC](AWCframeset.html) and [ASI](ASIframeset.html) converge on the [AIB](AIBframeset.html) interneuron in negative thermotaxis, whereas the [AIY](AIYframeset.html)/AIZ/[RIA](RIAframeset.html) network may function mainly in isothermal tracking ([Ma and Shen, 2012](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/32/1/1.long)). During associative learning between temperature and feeding state, starvation, a conditioning factor, downregulates AIZ activity through [calcineurin/TAX-6]( http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00006527), a calcium- activated phosphatase, leading to avoidance from Tc ([Kuhara and Mori, 2006](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/26/37/9355.long)).  - Functions in **locomotion:** Laser ablations of AIZ, like AIB and AWC, cause decrease in reversals and lead to large increases in the duration of forward movement ([Tsalik and Hobert, 2003](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/neu.10245/abstract;jsessionid=D8214EBC383488E3FCCD265C4AF8AB47); Iino and Yoshida, 2009). Since ablations of [AIY](AIYframeset.html) and AIZ cause opposite behavioral phenotpes, the synapses made by [AIY](AIYframeset.html) onto AIZ may be inhibitory. Alternatively, signals fom [AIY](AIYframeset.html) to AIZ could be processed in a downstream neuron such as [RIA](RIAframeset.html) ([de Bono and Maricq 2005](http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev.neuro.27.070203.144259)). - Functions in **chemotaxis:** Laser ablations of AIZ cause defects in the weathervane (slow turning of the animal by biased head swing) and pirouette (bout of sharp turns generated by frequent reversals followed by omega turns) responses (see [Nervous System-General Description](../../hermaphrodite/nervous/Neuroframeset.html)) leading to impaired chemotaxis ([Iino and Yoshida, 2009](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/29/17/5370.full#F1)).
AIZR.Receptor expression: ](http](http //www.wormatlas.org/NTRmainframe.htm)_**   - [SER-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00004777); tyramine receptor (expresses two separate splice variants) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0012-1606(03)00447-0))

ALA.Description: Has two processes that branch from the anterior portion of the cell body, project into the left or right side of the nerve ring and then migrate as far as the tail on the lateral cords, adjacent to excretory canals. Also sends a process along dorsal cord.
ALA.Function: _**   - Involved in inducing normal lethargus quiescence (i.e., cessation of pharyngeal pumping and locomotion during the lethargus periods (an EGF/[LET-23-](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002299)induced sleep-like state prior to molts). ALA neuron inhibits locomotion by inhibiting[ AVE](AVEframeset.html), which normally functions to promote locomotion. Synapse between ALA and[ AVE](AVEframeset.html) is contacted by the CEPsh glia and CEPsh cells inhibit synaptic transmission from ALA to [AVE](AVEframeset.html), promoting locomotion. ([Mulcahy and Ient 2010](http://www.springerlink.com/content/a253127112k76412/?MUD=MP); [Van Buskirk and Sternberg, 2007](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nn1981))
ALA.Innexin expression: _**   None yet reported, although described to have gap junctions in adult animals ([MoW](../../ver1/MoW_built0.92/toc.html))
ALA.Receptor expression: ](../../NTRmainframe.htm)_**   - [ACR-13 (LEV-8)](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00002975) - [ACR-4 (DES-2)](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00000955) - [SRA-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005036) ([Van Buskirk and Sternberg, 2010](http://dev.biologists.org/content/137/12/2065.long); [Towers et al., 200 5](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1471-4159.2004.02951.x/full); [Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.cell.com/retrieve/pii/0092867495901620))

ALML.Function: Along with [AVM](AVMframeset.html) and [PLM](PLMframeset.html), sense touch to the body and provide input to the command (inter) neurons ([PVC](PVCframeset.html), [AVB](AVBframeset.html), [AVD](AVDframeset.html), [AVA](AVAframeset.html)) via both synaptic connections and gap junctions ([Chalfie et al., 1985](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/reprint/5/4/956)). The touch cells form gap junctions with agonist interneurons and chemical synapses with the antagonist interneurons. Hence, the anterior touch cells ALML/R and [AVM](AVMframeset.html) form gap junctions with the backward movement interneuron [AVD](AVDframeset.html), but they provide synaptic input to the forward interneurons ([AVB](AVBframeset.html) and [PVC](PVCframeset.html)) ([Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See body touch circuit [here](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
ALML.Neurotransmitter: **[Glutamate](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html). Expresses VGluT,[ EAT-4](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001135;class=Gene) ([Lee et al., 1999](http **[Glutamate](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html). Expresses VGluT,[ EAT-4](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001135;class=Gene) ([Lee et al., 1999](http //www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3)).**
ALML.Receptor Expression: Express [MEC-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003166;class=Gene) (stomatin-like), [MEC-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003168;class=Gene) (degenerin), [MEC-10](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003174;class=Gene) (degenerin) which comprise part of a mechanosensory transduction channel ([Huang et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002333;class=Paper); [Lai et al., 1996](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/reprint/133/5/1071); [Huang and Chalfie, 1994](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00001871;class=Paper)). Express [MEC-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003173;class=Gene) which is suggested to provide an extracellular attachment point for the mechanosensory channels in touch cells ([Du et al., 1996](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002379;class=Paper)) and [MEC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene) which is part of the degenerin/epithelial Na+ channel complex ([Chelur et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005591;class=Paper)). Express glutamate receptor subunit, [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/21/5/1510.full)). Express alpha subunits of a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, [DEG-3](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000951;class=Gene) and [DES-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000955;class=Gene) ([Treinin and Chalfie, 1995](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WSS-4CWYS0K-R&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=6d77922c0d406fdedd8bb40382906482), [Treinin. et al., 1998](http://www.pnas.org/content/95/26/15492.long)). Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472), [Sanyal et al., 2004](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v23/n2/abs/7600057a.html)).

The touch cells form gap junctions with agonist interneurons and chemical synapses with the antagonist interneurons. Hence, the anterior touch cells ALML/R and [AVM](AVMframeset.html) form gap junctions with the backward movement interneuron [AVD](AVDframeset.html), but they provide synaptic input to the forward interneurons ([AVB](AVBframeset.html) and [PVC](PVCframeset.html)) ([Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). Expresses VGluT,[ EAT-4](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001135;class=Gene) ([Lee et al., 1999](http **[Glutamate](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html).
