Express the FMRFamide-related neuropeptide (FaRP), [ FLP-18 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=flp-18)([Rogers et al., 2003](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00006174;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide-like protein, [NLP-3](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003741;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
M3R.Receptor Expression: Express [ glutamate receptor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) subunit [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

M4.Description: The cell body of M4 is located dorsally at the level of the nerve ring. M4 sends two ventral branches, which run around the nerve ring on each side. These processes then cross to the other side and continue to run posteriorly in the subventral nerve cords. In the isthmus, M4 makes neuromuscular synapses on pm5. The two processes turn dorsally in the terminal bulb commissure, meet each other in gap junctions and run anteriorly in the dorsal nerve cord for some variable distance through the isthmus before ending. These also make synapses on pm5 on the dorsal side. Unlike other pharyngeal motor neurons, M4 contains darkly-staining vesicles, similar to the 65 nm dense core vesicles associated with some amphidial neurones ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/albertson_1975/results.html)).
M4.Function: M4 is essential for feeding in wild- type worms. M4 synapses on the isthmus and the terminal bulb, and is necessary for posterior isthmus peristalsis ([Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). Worms lacking M4 continue pumping, however, bacteria become trapped in corpus and anterior isthmus and these worms fail to grow since they can not pass the food to their intestines.
M4.Neurotransmitter: Possibly [acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) ([Duerr et al., 2008](http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/cne.21551)[](http://elegans.swmed.edu/wli/%5Bmwwm94p39%5D/?%5Cb%5Bi%C3%AD%C3%AC%C3%AE%C3%AF%5D6%5Cb)). Express the FMRFamide-related neuropeptide (FaRP), [FLP-21](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001464;class=Gene) ([Rogers et al., 2003](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00006174;class=Paper)).
M4.Receptor Expression: Expresses G-alpha(s) coupled 5-HT7-like receptor, [SER7b ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004780;class=Gene)([Hobson et al., 2003](http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118871389/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0)). Expresses glutamate receptor subunit [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)).

M5.Description: M5 is located subdorsally on the left, posterior to pm7. It sends one dorsal and one ventral process. Dorsal process makes a half circle running behind pm7. The two processes then cross on the ventral side and run anteriorly adjacent to the ventral marginal cell until they reach the terminal bulb commissure. The processes pass under the cell bodies of motor neurons [M2](M2frameset.html) and continue to meet in gap junctions on the dorsal side of the terminal bulb commissure. Along the way they also send short, posterior branches which run on either side of the subdorsal marginal cells ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/albertson_1975/results.html)).
M5.Neurotransmitter: Possibly [acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) ([Duerr et al., 2008](http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/cne.21551)[](http://elegans.swmed.edu/wli/%5Bmwwm94p39%5D/?%5Cb%5Bi%C3%AD%C3%AC%C3%AE%C3%AF%5D6%5Cb)). Express FMRFamide-like peptide, [FLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001444;class=Gene) precursor ([Nelson et al., 1998](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003158;class=Paper)).

MCL.Description: MC's are a pair of cholinergic excitatory (motor) neurons. Anteriorly, they have free subcuticular (putative proprioceptive) endings between pm3 and pm4. Posteriorly, each cell sends a process which enters the nerve ring from the subventral nerve cord and makes a loop around the nerve ring. On the dorsal side these processes send a branch to the outside edge of the pharynx under the marginal cell 2 (mc2) of the opposite side. Once they reach the opposite ventral side, each process continues to run posteriorly under the ventral marginal cell, terminating at the very anterior of the isthmus. Their most prominent connections are gap junctions to [M2](M2frameset.html) and they synapse strongly on the mc2 ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/albertson_1975/results.html)). MC's also synapse onto pm4 (L. Avery pers. comm.)
MCL.Function: MC's control the frequency of pharyngeal pumping ([Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). They initiate pharyngeal muscle action potentials, and hence, function as pacemakers of pumping. Release of Ach from MC neurons stimulates the muscle via a postsynaptic nicotinic ACh receptor encoded by [_eat-2 _](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001133;class=Gene)([Niacaris and Avery, 2003](http://jeb.biologists.org/cgi/content/full/206/2/223);[ McKay et al., 2004](http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?tool=pubmed&pubmedid=15020415)). In [_eat-2_](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001133;class=Gene)_ _mutants MC is decoupled from pharyngeal muscle and the pharynx is unable to pump rapidly in the presence of food. Modulators of pharyngeal pumping such as exogenous serotonin mostly act through MC neurons.
MCL.Neurotransmitter: [Acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) ([Niacaris and Avery, 2003](http://jeb.biologists.org/content/206/2/223.long); [Raizen et al, 1995](http://www.genetics.org/cgi/reprint/141/4/1365)). Express the FMRFamide-related neuropeptide (FaRP), [FLP-21](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001464;class=Gene) ([Rogers et al., 2003](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00006174;class=Paper)).

MCR.Description: MC's are a pair of cholinergic excitatory (motor) neurons. Anteriorly, they have free subcuticular (putative proprioceptive) endings between pm3 and pm4. Posteriorly, each cell sends a process which enters the nerve ring from the subventral nerve cord and makes a loop around the nerve ring. On the dorsal side these processes send a branch to the outside edge of the pharynx under the marginal cell 2 (mc2) of the opposite side. Once they reach the opposite ventral side, each process continues to run posteriorly under the ventral marginal cell, terminating at the very anterior of the isthmus. Their most prominent connections are gap junctions to [M2](M2frameset.html) and they synapse strongly on the mc2 ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/albertson_1975/results.html)). MC's also synapse onto pm4 (L. Avery pers. comm.)
MCR.Function: MC's control the frequency of pharyngeal pumping ([Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). They initiate pharyngeal muscle action potentials, and hence, function as pacemakers of pumping. Release of Ach from MC neurons stimulates the muscle via a postsynaptic nicotinic ACh receptor encoded by [_eat-2 _](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001133;class=Gene)([Niacaris and Avery, 2003](http://jeb.biologists.org/cgi/content/full/206/2/223);[ McKay et al., 2004](http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?tool=pubmed&pubmedid=15020415)). In [_eat-2_](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001133;class=Gene)_ _mutants MC is decoupled from pharyngeal muscle and the pharynx is unable to pump rapidly in the presence of food. Modulators of pharyngeal pumping such as exogenous serotonin mostly act through MC neurons.
MCR.Neurotransmitter: [Acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) ([Niacaris and Avery, 2003](http://jeb.biologists.org/content/206/2/223.long); [Raizen et al, 1995](http://www.genetics.org/cgi/reprint/141/4/1365)). Express the FMRFamide-related neuropeptide (FaRP), [FLP-21](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001464;class=Gene) ([Rogers et al., 2003](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00006174;class=Paper)).

MI.Description: MI is a unipolar neuron which is located in the dorsal nerve cord, anterior to the pharyngeal nerve ring. Its process makes a complete turn around the ring in a clockwise or counterclockwise fashion ending in dorsal cord. This neuron makes variable synapses that often have both nerve and muscle as the post synaptic cells (see connectivity diagram below) ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/albertson_1975/results.html)).

NSML.Description: NSM cell bodies are located in the pharyngeal subventral nerve cords just anterior to the nerve ring. These cells are bipolar with one major process from each cell bifurcating near the cell body to two thick processes. There is also a third, long, thin process that originates from the cell body and possibly functions as proprioceptive ([Axang et al., 2008](http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-213X/8/38)). One of the two main branches crosses to the opposite side, turns dorsally within the nerve ring and continues its trajectory posteriorly within the dorsal nerve cord of the isthmus. The other branch runs posteriorly within the subventral nerve cord of the isthmus. These processes run at the most outside edge of the nerve cords, very close to pseudocoelom, and make synapses to the pharyngeal basement membrane and muscle cells. Both processes terminate before reaching the terminal bulb. Within the isthmus these processes periodically swell to form varicosities filled with large, lightly- and darkly-staining membrane bound vesicles, as well as small clear vesicles. Along with these major processes NSM's also have small, synapse-free processes with free endings just under the cuticle of the pharyngeal lumen at the boundary between the corpus and isthmus (where bacteria accumulate). These endings are attached to the adjacent muscle cells by desmosomes and are thought to act as stretch (proprioceptive) receptors. These processes can not be seen at the light microscopic level (therefore not obvious in GFP images below). They have also been omitted from the drawn images below. The NSM's receive extensive synapses from I2 (see connectivity diagram below) ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/albertson_1975/results.html)). NSM's are serotonergic but they are also able to take up exogenous serotonin via a serotonin reuptake transporter, [MOD-5](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003387;class=Gene) ([Ranganathan et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/16/5871)).
NSML.Function: Initially suggested to have neurohumoral function signaling the presence of food to the body since NSM's appear secretory by morphology and have processes that run in close apposition to the pseudocoelom over most of their lengths ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/albertson_1975/results.html), [Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). They were postulated to sense bacteria in their lumen by their proprioceptive endings and transmit this to the rest of the body by secretions to the pseudocoelomic fluid. The presence of food leads to increased pharyngeal pumping, decreased locomotion and increased egg-laying behavior. Exogenous application of serotonin also induces these responses supporting the hypothesis NSM's can function neurohumorally by serotonin secretion. However, ablation of NSM's have only subtle effects on pumping suggesting they may not play any important role in this behavior ([Avery et al., 1993](http://www.genetics.org/cgi/reprint/134/2/455), [Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). When placed on a bacterial lawn, previously food-deprived animals slow down their locomotion to a higher degree compared to well-fed animals. This phenomenon is described as "the enhanced slowing response". When NSM's are ablated there is a small but significant decrease in the enhanced slowing response suggesting NSM's contribute to this behavior ([Sawin et al., 2000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004195;class=Paper)).
NSML.Neurotransmitter: [Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamines/monoamines.html#sec5) ([Horvitz et al., 1982](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00000552;class=Paper);[ Sze et al., 2000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003903;class=Paper)). [Glutamate](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) ([Lee et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3)). Express neuropeptide-like proteins, [ NLP-13](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003751;class=Gene), [NLP-18](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003756;class=Gene), [NLP-19](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003757;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
NSML.Receptor Expression: Express glutamate receptor subunits,[ GLR-7](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001618;class=Gene) and [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Express a splice variant of the tyramine receptor [SER-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)). Suggested to express [AEX-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000085;class=Gene), a 7-transmembrane domain protein with homology to the G protein-coupled receptor family ([Round et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00016737;class=Paper)).

NSMR.Description: NSM cell bodies are located in the pharyngeal subventral nerve cords just anterior to the nerve ring. These cells are bipolar with one major process from each cell bifurcating near the cell body to two thick processes. There is also a third, long, thin process that originates from the cell body and possibly functions as proprioceptive ([Axang et al., 2008](http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-213X/8/38)). One of the two main branches crosses to the opposite side, turns dorsally within the nerve ring and continues its trajectory posteriorly within the dorsal nerve cord of the isthmus. The other branch runs posteriorly within the subventral nerve cord of the isthmus. These processes run at the most outside edge of the nerve cords, very close to pseudocoelom, and make synapses to the pharyngeal basement membrane and muscle cells. Both processes terminate before reaching the terminal bulb. Within the isthmus these processes periodically swell to form varicosities filled with large, lightly- and darkly-staining membrane bound vesicles, as well as small clear vesicles. Along with these major processes NSM's also have small, synapse-free processes with free endings just under the cuticle of the pharyngeal lumen at the boundary between the corpus and isthmus (where bacteria accumulate). These endings are attached to the adjacent muscle cells by desmosomes and are thought to act as stretch (proprioceptive) receptors. These processes can not be seen at the light microscopic level (therefore not obvious in GFP images below). They have also been omitted from the drawn images below. The NSM's receive extensive synapses from I2 (see connectivity diagram below) ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/albertson_1975/results.html)). NSM's are serotonergic but they are also able to take up exogenous serotonin via a serotonin reuptake transporter, [MOD-5](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003387;class=Gene) ([Ranganathan et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/16/5871)).
NSMR.Function: Initially suggested to have neurohumoral function signaling the presence of food to the body since NSM's appear secretory by morphology and have processes that run in close apposition to the pseudocoelom over most of their lengths ([Albertson and Thomson, 1976](http://www.wormatlas.org/albertson_1975/results.html), [Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). They were postulated to sense bacteria in their lumen by their proprioceptive endings and transmit this to the rest of the body by secretions to the pseudocoelomic fluid. The presence of food leads to increased pharyngeal pumping, decreased locomotion and increased egg-laying behavior. Exogenous application of serotonin also induces these responses supporting the hypothesis NSM's can function neurohumorally by serotonin secretion. However, ablation of NSM's have only subtle effects on pumping suggesting they may not play any important role in this behavior ([Avery et al., 1993](http://www.genetics.org/cgi/reprint/134/2/455), [Avery and Thomas, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.820)). When placed on a bacterial lawn, previously food-deprived animals slow down their locomotion to a higher degree compared to well-fed animals. This phenomenon is described as "the enhanced slowing response". When NSM's are ablated there is a small but significant decrease in the enhanced slowing response suggesting NSM's contribute to this behavior ([Sawin et al., 2000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004195;class=Paper)).
NSMR.Neurotransmitter: [Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamines/monoamines.html#sec5) ([Horvitz et al., 1982](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00000552;class=Paper);[ Sze et al., 2000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003903;class=Paper)). [Glutamate](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) ([Lee et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3)). Express neuropeptide-like proteins, [ NLP-13](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003751;class=Gene), [NLP-18](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003756;class=Gene), [NLP-19](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003757;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
NSMR.Receptor Expression: Express glutamate receptor subunits,[ GLR-7](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001618;class=Gene) and [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Express a splice variant of the tyramine receptor [SER-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)). Suggested to express [AEX-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000085;class=Gene), a 7-transmembrane domain protein with homology to the G protein-coupled receptor family ([Round et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00016737;class=Paper)).

OLLL.Description: Neurons of [outer labial lateral sensilla](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Outerlabialsensilla34), [ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis.2/ciliumbiogenesis.html) with striated rootlets.
OLLL.Receptor Expression: Express a splice variant of the tyramine receptor[ SER-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)).

OLLR.Description: Neurons of [outer labial lateral sensilla](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Outerlabialsensilla34), [ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis.2/ciliumbiogenesis.html) with striated rootlets.
OLLR.Receptor Expression: Express a splice variant of the tyramine receptor[ SER-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)).

OLQDL.Description: Neurons of [outer labial lateral sensilla](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Outerlabialsensilla34), [ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis.2/ciliumbiogenesis.html) with striated rootlets.
OLQDL.Function: When worms are touched on either the dorsal or ventral sides of their nose with an eyelash, they interrupt the normal pattern of foraging and undergo an aversive head-withdrawal reflex. This simple reflex is mediated by two classes of mechanosensory neurons (OLQ and[ IL1](IL1frameset.html)) and their synaptic targets, the [RMD](RMDframeset.html) motor neurons. Killing any of these cells, alone or in combination, diminishes the head withdrawal reflex. [ IL1](IL1frameset.html), OLQ, and [RMD](RMDframeset.html) also regulate spontaneous foraging movements. Laser operated animals lacking[ IL1](IL1frameset.html) and OLQ forage abnormally slowly and make exaggerated dorsal and ventral nose turns ([Hart et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002309;class=Paper); [Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See [head withdrawal and foraging circuit](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
OLQDL.Lineage: AB alapapapaa, AB alapppapaa AB plpaaappaa, AB prpaaappaa
OLQDL.Receptor Expression: Express mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel protein [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)). Express osm-9/capsaicin receptor related TRPV protein, [OCR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003841;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

OLQDR.Description: Neurons of [outer labial lateral sensilla](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Outerlabialsensilla34), [ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis.2/ciliumbiogenesis.html) with striated rootlets.
OLQDR.Function: When worms are touched on either the dorsal or ventral sides of their nose with an eyelash, they interrupt the normal pattern of foraging and undergo an aversive head-withdrawal reflex. This simple reflex is mediated by two classes of mechanosensory neurons (OLQ and[ IL1](IL1frameset.html)) and their synaptic targets, the [RMD](RMDframeset.html) motor neurons. Killing any of these cells, alone or in combination, diminishes the head withdrawal reflex. [ IL1](IL1frameset.html), OLQ, and [RMD](RMDframeset.html) also regulate spontaneous foraging movements. Laser operated animals lacking[ IL1](IL1frameset.html) and OLQ forage abnormally slowly and make exaggerated dorsal and ventral nose turns ([Hart et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002309;class=Paper); [Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See [head withdrawal and foraging circuit](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
OLQDR.Lineage: AB alapapapaa, AB alapppapaa AB plpaaappaa, AB prpaaappaa
OLQDR.Receptor Expression: Express mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel protein [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)). Express osm-9/capsaicin receptor related TRPV protein, [OCR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003841;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

OLQVL.Description: Neurons of [outer labial lateral sensilla](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Outerlabialsensilla34), [ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis.2/ciliumbiogenesis.html) with striated rootlets.
OLQVL.Function: When worms are touched on either the dorsal or ventral sides of their nose with an eyelash, they interrupt the normal pattern of foraging and undergo an aversive head-withdrawal reflex. This simple reflex is mediated by two classes of mechanosensory neurons (OLQ and[ IL1](IL1frameset.html)) and their synaptic targets, the [RMD](RMDframeset.html) motor neurons. Killing any of these cells, alone or in combination, diminishes the head withdrawal reflex. [ IL1](IL1frameset.html), OLQ, and [RMD](RMDframeset.html) also regulate spontaneous foraging movements. Laser operated animals lacking[ IL1](IL1frameset.html) and OLQ forage abnormally slowly and make exaggerated dorsal and ventral nose turns ([Hart et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002309;class=Paper); [Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See [head withdrawal and foraging circuit](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
OLQVL.Lineage: AB alapapapaa, AB alapppapaa AB plpaaappaa, AB prpaaappaa
OLQVL.Receptor Expression: Express mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel protein [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)). Express osm-9/capsaicin receptor related TRPV protein, [OCR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003841;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

OLQVR.Description: Neurons of [outer labial lateral sensilla](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Outerlabialsensilla34), [ciliated endings](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ciliumbiogenesis.2/ciliumbiogenesis.html) with striated rootlets.
OLQVR.Function: When worms are touched on either the dorsal or ventral sides of their nose with an eyelash, they interrupt the normal pattern of foraging and undergo an aversive head-withdrawal reflex. This simple reflex is mediated by two classes of mechanosensory neurons (OLQ and[ IL1](IL1frameset.html)) and their synaptic targets, the [RMD](RMDframeset.html) motor neurons. Killing any of these cells, alone or in combination, diminishes the head withdrawal reflex. [ IL1](IL1frameset.html), OLQ, and [RMD](RMDframeset.html) also regulate spontaneous foraging movements. Laser operated animals lacking[ IL1](IL1frameset.html) and OLQ forage abnormally slowly and make exaggerated dorsal and ventral nose turns ([Hart et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002309;class=Paper); [Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See [head withdrawal and foraging circuit](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
OLQVR.Lineage: AB alapapapaa, AB alapppapaa AB plpaaappaa, AB prpaaappaa
OLQVR.Receptor Expression: Express mammalian capsaicin receptor-like channel protein [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)). Express osm-9/capsaicin receptor related TRPV protein, [OCR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003841;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

PDA.Description: During the second larval stage (L2), the rectal epithelial cell Y withdraws from the epithelium, migrates anterodorsally, and then becomes the PDA neuron through a transdifferentiation event while P12.pa, born at the end of the L1 stage just anterior to the position of Y, replaces Y in the rectum, completing the toroid with B epithelial cell. ([Sulston and Horvitz 1977](http://www.wormatlas.org/SulstonpostembVNC_1976/Sulston_VNC_1976.html)). In male, Y divides and the anterior daughter becomes PDA. The dorsal cord process of PDA ends in the posterior part of the body (O. Hobert, pers. comm.). Hermaphrodites and males exhibit some differences in PDA connectivity.
PDA.Function: Innervates posterior dorsal body wall muscles.
PDA.Receptor Expression: ** Expresses an excitatory [GABA](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_gaba/gaba.html) receptor subunit, EXP-1 ([Beg and Jorgensen, 2003](httpExpresses [UNC-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00006748;class=Gene), a DEG/ENaC family member homologous to subunits of a candidate mechanically gated ion channel ([Tavernarakis et al., 1997](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002646;class=Paper)).

PDB.Description: Motor neuron. Born postembryonically. Sends process towards tail which turn around and join dorsal cord.
PDB.Function: Innervates posterior dorsal body wall muscles.
PDB.Receptor Expression: Expresses [UNC-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00006748;class=Gene), a DEG/ENaC family member homologous to subunits of a candidate mechanically gated ion channel ([Tavernarakis et al., 1997](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002646;class=Paper)).

PDEL.Description: Posterior deirids, postembryonically born. Sensory receptors located next to dorsal body wall muscle along the lateral side of the posterior body.
PDEL.Function: When well-fed _C. elegans_ hermaphrodites are washed clean of bacteria and then reintroduced to the bacterial lawn, they move more slowly than when transferred to an environment without bacteria. This behavior is described as "basal slowing response". The three classes of dopaminergic neurons ([CEP](CEPframeset.html)s, [ADE](ADEframeset.html)s, and PDEs) function redundantly to sense the [mechanosensory](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html) stimulus from bacteria and mediate the motor circuit to control this behavioral change ([Sawin et al., 2000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004195;class=Paper)).
PDEL.Receptor Expression: Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001053;class=Gene) ([Suo et al., 2003](http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/118871307/HTMLSTART) ).

PDER.Description: Posterior deirids, postembryonically born. Sensory receptors located next to dorsal body wall muscle along the lateral side of the posterior body.
PDER.Function: When well-fed _C. elegans_ hermaphrodites are washed clean of bacteria and then reintroduced to the bacterial lawn, they move more slowly than when transferred to an environment without bacteria. This behavior is described as "basal slowing response". The three classes of dopaminergic neurons ([CEP](CEPframeset.html)s, [ADE](ADEframeset.html)s, and PDEs) function redundantly to sense the [mechanosensory](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html) stimulus from bacteria and mediate the motor circuit to control this behavioral change ([Sawin et al., 2000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004195;class=Paper)).
PDER.Receptor Expression: Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001053;class=Gene) ([Suo et al., 2003](http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/118871307/HTMLSTART) ).

PHAL.Function: Modulate chemorepulsion behavior in worms ([Hilliard et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005242;class=Paper)).
PHAL.Neurotransmitter: Express neuropeptide-like proteins, [NLP-7](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003745;class=Gene) and [NLP-14 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003752;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
PHAL.Receptor Expression: Expresses orphan receptor (chemosensory/odorant?) guanylyl cyclase, [GCY-12](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001538;class=Gene) ([Yu et al., 1997](http://www.pnas.org/content/94/7/3384.long)). Express TRPV channel proteins, [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)) and[ OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003839;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper)). Express G protein-coupled serpentine receptors, [SRG-13](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005170;class=Gene) and [SRB-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005071;class=Gene) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002314;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

PHAR.Function: Modulate chemorepulsion behavior in worms ([Hilliard et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005242;class=Paper)).
PHAR.Neurotransmitter: Express neuropeptide-like proteins, [NLP-7](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003745;class=Gene) and [NLP-14 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003752;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
PHAR.Receptor Expression: Expresses orphan receptor (chemosensory/odorant?) guanylyl cyclase, [GCY-12](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001538;class=Gene) ([Yu et al., 1997](http://www.pnas.org/content/94/7/3384.long)). Express TRPV channel proteins, [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)) and[ OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003839;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005350;class=Paper)). Express G protein-coupled serpentine receptors, [SRG-13](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005170;class=Gene) and [SRB-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005071;class=Gene) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002314;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

PHBL.Description: **[Phasmid neurons](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Phasmidsensilla36)**   Neurotransmitter:** [Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamine s/monoamines.html#sec5), based on serotonin immunoreactivity ([Sawin et al., 2 000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004195;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide-like protein, [NLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003739;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
PHBL.Function: **Modulate chemorepulsion behavior in worms ([Hilliard et al., 2002](http **Modulate chemorepulsion behavior in worms ([Hilliard et al., 2002](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005242;class=Paper)).**   Receptor Expression:** Express TRPV channel proteins, [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)) and[ OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003839;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper000053 50;class=Paper)). Express G protein-coupled serpentine receptor, [SRB-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005071;class=Gene) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper0000 2314;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

PHBR.Description: **[Phasmid neurons](../../hermaphrodite/neuronalsupport/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Phasmidsensilla36)**   Neurotransmitter:** [Serotonin](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_monoamine s/monoamines.html#sec5), based on serotonin immunoreactivity ([Sawin et al., 2 000](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004195;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide-like protein, [NLP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003739;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
PHBR.Function: **Modulate chemorepulsion behavior in worms ([Hilliard et al., 2002](http **Modulate chemorepulsion behavior in worms ([Hilliard et al., 2002](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005242;class=Paper)).**   Receptor Expression:** Express TRPV channel proteins, [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)) and[ OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003839;class=Gene) ([Tobin et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper000053 50;class=Paper)). Express G protein-coupled serpentine receptor, [SRB-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005071;class=Gene) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper0000 2314;class=Paper)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)).

PHCL.Description: **Possibly sensory in[ tail spike](../../hermaphrodite/atypical/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Tailspikescaffoldcells2). Striated rootlet in male. Postembryonically born.**   Neurotransmitter:
PHCL.Function: **[Mechanosensory](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensa tion/mechanosensation.html)?**  Receptor Expression:** Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Sanyal et al., 2004](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v23/n2/full/7600057a.html)).
PHCL.In MoW: ** [PHC](http** [PHC](http //www.wormatlas.org/ver1/MoW_built0.92/cells/phc.html)**   Male Wiring Project: **[PHCL](http://worms.aecom.yu.edu/neuron.php?name=PHCL&c ontinNum=3159&desc=Phasmid Sensory Neuron), [PHCR](http://worms.aecom.yu.edu/n euron.php?name=PHCR&continNum=1456&desc=Phasmid Sensory Neuron)

PHCR.Description: **Possibly sensory in[ tail spike](../../hermaphrodite/atypical/jump.html?newLink=mainframe.htm&newAnchor=Tailspikescaffoldcells2). Striated rootlet in male. Postembryonically born.**   Neurotransmitter:
PHCR.Function: **[Mechanosensory](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensa tion/mechanosensation.html)?**  Receptor Expression:** Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Sanyal et al., 2004](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v23/n2/full/7600057a.html)).
PHCR.In MoW: ** [PHC](http** [PHC](http //www.wormatlas.org/ver1/MoW_built0.92/cells/phc.html)**   Male Wiring Project: **[PHCL](http://worms.aecom.yu.edu/neuron.php?name=PHCL&c ontinNum=3159&desc=Phasmid Sensory Neuron), [PHCR](http://worms.aecom.yu.edu/n euron.php?name=PHCR&continNum=1456&desc=Phasmid Sensory Neuron)

PLML.Description: Posterior lateral microtubule cells, touch receptor neurons. Send ventrally directed processes to ventral cord.
PLML.Function: Along with [AVM](AVMframeset.html) and [ALM](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/Wormatlas%202.0%20073109/wormatlas/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/ALMframeset.html), sense touch to the body and provide input to the command (inter)neurons ([PVC](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/PVDframeset.html), [AVB](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVBframeset.html), [AVD](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVDframeset.html), [AVA](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVAframeset.html)) via both synaptic connections and gap junctions ([Chalfie et al., 1985](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/reprint/5/4/956)). The touch cells form gap junctions with agonist interneurons and chemical synapses with the antagonist interneurons. Hence, the anterior touch cells PLML/R form gap junctions with the forward movement interneuron [PVC](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/PVDframeset.html), but they provide synaptic input to the backward interneurons [AVA](AVAframeset.html) and [AVD](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVDframeset.html) ([Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See body touch circuit [here](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
PLML.Receptor Expression: Express [MEC-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003166;class=Gene) (stomatin-like), [MEC-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003168;class=Gene) (degenerin), [MEC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=mec-6;class=Locus) which comprise part of a mechanosensory transduction channel ([Huang et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002333;class=Paper); [Lai et al., 1996](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/reprint/133/5/1071); [Chelur et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01205)). Express [MEC-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003173;class=Gene)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=mec-9;class=Locus) which is suggested to provide an extracellular attachment point for the mechanosensory channels in touch cells ([Du et al., 1996](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002379;class=Paper)) and [MEC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene) which is part of the degenerin/epithelial Na+ channel complex ([Chelur et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01205)). Express glutamate receptor subunit, [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Express alpha subunits of a nicotinic [acetylcholine receptor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html#sec6), [DEG-3](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=deg-3;class=Locus) and [DES-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000955;class=Gene) ([Treinin and Chalfie, 1995](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WSS-4CWYS0K-R&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=6d77922c0d406fdedd8bb40382906482);[ Treinin et al., 1998](http://www.pnas.org/content/95/26/15492.long)). Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Sanyal et al., 2004](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v23/n2/abs/7600057a.html)).

PLMR.Description: Posterior lateral microtubule cells, touch receptor neurons. Send ventrally directed processes to ventral cord.
PLMR.Function: Along with [AVM](AVMframeset.html) and [ALM](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/Wormatlas%202.0%20073109/wormatlas/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/ALMframeset.html), sense touch to the body and provide input to the command (inter)neurons ([PVC](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/PVDframeset.html), [AVB](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVBframeset.html), [AVD](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVDframeset.html), [AVA](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVAframeset.html)) via both synaptic connections and gap junctions ([Chalfie et al., 1985](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/reprint/5/4/956)). The touch cells form gap junctions with agonist interneurons and chemical synapses with the antagonist interneurons. Hence, the anterior touch cells PLML/R form gap junctions with the forward movement interneuron [PVC](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/PVDframeset.html), but they provide synaptic input to the backward interneurons [AVA](AVAframeset.html) and [AVD](file:///C:/Documents%20and%20Settings/Laura/Desktop/WORMATLAS%20Site%20development/Wormatlas072009/neurons/Individual%20Neurons/AVDframeset.html) ([Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). See body touch circuit [here](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.figgrp.787).
PLMR.Receptor Expression: Express [MEC-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003166;class=Gene) (stomatin-like), [MEC-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003168;class=Gene) (degenerin), [MEC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=mec-6;class=Locus) which comprise part of a mechanosensory transduction channel ([Huang et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002333;class=Paper); [Lai et al., 1996](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/reprint/133/5/1071); [Chelur et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01205)). Express [MEC-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003173;class=Gene)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=mec-9;class=Locus) which is suggested to provide an extracellular attachment point for the mechanosensory channels in touch cells ([Du et al., 1996](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002379;class=Paper)) and [MEC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene) which is part of the degenerin/epithelial Na+ channel complex ([Chelur et al., 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01205)). Express glutamate receptor subunit, [GLR-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001619;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Express alpha subunits of a nicotinic [acetylcholine receptor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html#sec6), [DEG-3](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=deg-3;class=Locus) and [DES-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000955;class=Gene) ([Treinin and Chalfie, 1995](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WSS-4CWYS0K-R&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=6d77922c0d406fdedd8bb40382906482);[ Treinin et al., 1998](http://www.pnas.org/content/95/26/15492.long)). Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Sanyal et al., 2004](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v23/n2/abs/7600057a.html)).

PLNL.Description: The processes of PLN's run closely associated with those of [PLM](PLMframeset.html)'s in the posterior half of the animal. At midbody, they join the ventral sublateral cords via bilateral, short ventrally directed commissures. Anteriorly, they enter the ventral cord via amphidial commissures. These neurons are postembryonically born.
PLNL.Receptor Expression: Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)).

PLNR.Description: The processes of PLN's run closely associated with those of [PLM](PLMframeset.html)'s in the posterior half of the animal. At midbody, they join the ventral sublateral cords via bilateral, short ventrally directed commissures. Anteriorly, they enter the ventral cord via amphidial commissures. These neurons are postembryonically born.
PLNR.Receptor Expression: Express the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)).

PQR.Description: Single neuron with basal body. It is directly exposed to the pseudocoelomic body fluid. An anterior process projects into preanal gangion and usually ends just posterior to the vulva, although can be slightly shorter or longer. Posterior process is ensheathed by PHso2L cell. Postembryonically born from the left Q neuroblast (QL) and migrates posteriorly to a position near the phasmid neurons in the left lumbar ganglion See a [3-D reconstruction of PQR](../../movies/PQR.mov) by R. Newbury & Moerman lab. (Cell labels are shown below. 3-D movie was created from confocal images of a strain expressing the GFP marker linked to the promoter for [_ZC53 .7_](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene /gene?name=ZC53.7) using Zeiss LSM 5 Pascal software v. 3.2).
PQR.Function: ** Along with [AQR](AQRframeset.html), [URX](URXframeset.html) and [AUA](AUAframeset.html), [PQR](PQRframeset.html) regulate social feeding (or aggregation on a bacterial lawn) and bordering (the accumulation of animals on the thickest part of a bacterial lawn) behavior since suppressing the activity of [AQR](AQRframeset.html), [PQR](PQRframeset.html), and [URX](URXframeset.html) neurons inhibits social feeding ([Coates and de Bono , 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)) . [AQR](AQRframeset.html), [PQR](PQRframeset.html) and [URX](URXframeset.html) function as sensors of environmental oxygen which is a quantitative regulator of social feeding ([Gray et al., 2004](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?n ame=WBPaper00024211;class=Paper)). Decreases in oxygen leads to a dose- dependent suppression of social feeding behavior and bordering. Oxygen acts in parallel to [NPR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) in regulating social feeding behavior.
PQR.Receptor Expression: Expresses orphan receptor (chemosensory/odorant?) guanylyl cyclase, [GCY-32](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001552;class=Gene) ([Yu et al., 1997](http://www.pnas.org/content/94/7/3384.long)). Express neuropeptide Y receptor like protein, [NPR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003807;class=Gene) which mediates social feeding behavior ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005512;class=Paper)). Express specific soluble guanylate cyclase homologue,[ GCY-35 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001555;class=Gene)which binds molecular oxygen and mediates oxygen sensation ([Gray et al., 2004](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00024211;class=Paper)).

PVDL.Description: Born postembryonically (see [V lineage](../../images/HVTlineages.jpg)). PVDL/R have extensive branching pattern in adult animals (Hobert O. & Treinin M., pers. comm). In larval stages 3 major processes are discerned; one anteriorly directed, one posteriorly directed and one ventrally directed. These processes show short extensions and branches along their length. As the animal ages, this branching pattern is elaborated extensively and covers most of the body.
PVDL.Function: Putative stretch-sensing [mechanosensor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html). PVD mediates a response to harsh mechanical stimuli ([Way and Chalfie, 1989](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/3/12a/1823.long)). Animals in which PVD neurons are laser-ablated fail to respond to harsh touch to the central region of the body but can can respond to harsh head and tail tap. PVD is possibly not involved in the circuit that mediates suppression of pumping in response to a touch stimulus in adults ([Keane and Avery, 2003](http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?tool=pubmed&pubmedid=12750328))
PVDL.Neurotransmitter: [Glutamate](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html). Expresses VGluT,[ EAT-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001135;class=Gene) ([Lee et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3)). Express neuropeptide-like protein, [NLP-11](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003749;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
PVDL.Receptor Expression: ** Express [MEC-10](http //wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003174;class=Gene) (degenerin) which comprise part of a mechanosensory transduction channel ([Huang and Chalfie, 1994](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=%5Bcgc1871%5D;class=Paper)), [MEC-9](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003173;class=Gene) which is suggested to provide an extracellular attachment point for the mechanosensory channels in touch cells ([Du et al., 1996](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002379;class=Paper)) and [MEC-6](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene) which is part of the degenerin/epithelial Na+ channel complex ([Chelur et al., 2002](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005591;class=Paper)). Express TRPV channel protein [OSM-9](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http //www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)). Express a splice variant of the tyramine receptor [SER-2](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http //www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472), [Rex and Komuniecki, 2002](http //www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/118943670/HTMLSTART)). Express alpha subunits of a nicotinic [acetylcholine receptor](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html#sec6), [DEG-3](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=deg-3;class=Locus) and [DES-2](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000955;class=Gene) ([Treinin and Chalfie, 1995](http //www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WSS-4CWYS0K-R&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=6d77922c0d406fdedd8bb40382906482);[ Treinin et al., 1998](httpExpress[ glutamate receptor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) subunit, [GLR-4 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001615;class=Gene)([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)).

PVDR.Description: Born postembryonically (see [V lineage](../../images/HVTlineages.jpg)). PVDL/R have extensive branching pattern in adult animals (Hobert O. & Treinin M., pers. comm). In larval stages 3 major processes are discerned; one anteriorly directed, one posteriorly directed and one ventrally directed. These processes show short extensions and branches along their length. As the animal ages, this branching pattern is elaborated extensively and covers most of the body.
PVDR.Function: Putative stretch-sensing [mechanosensor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html). PVD mediates a response to harsh mechanical stimuli ([Way and Chalfie, 1989](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/3/12a/1823.long)). Animals in which PVD neurons are laser-ablated fail to respond to harsh touch to the central region of the body but can can respond to harsh head and tail tap. PVD is possibly not involved in the circuit that mediates suppression of pumping in response to a touch stimulus in adults ([Keane and Avery, 2003](http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?tool=pubmed&pubmedid=12750328))
PVDR.Neurotransmitter: [Glutamate](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html). Expresses VGluT,[ EAT-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001135;class=Gene) ([Lee et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/159#F3)). Express neuropeptide-like protein, [NLP-11](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003749;class=Gene) ([Nathoo et al., 2001](http://www.pnas.org/content/98/24/14000.long)).
PVDR.Receptor Expression: ** Express [MEC-10](http //wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003174;class=Gene) (degenerin) which comprise part of a mechanosensory transduction channel ([Huang and Chalfie, 1994](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=%5Bcgc1871%5D;class=Paper)), [MEC-9](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003173;class=Gene) which is suggested to provide an extracellular attachment point for the mechanosensory channels in touch cells ([Du et al., 1996](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002379;class=Paper)) and [MEC-6](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene) which is part of the degenerin/epithelial Na+ channel complex ([Chelur et al., 2002](http //www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005591;class=Paper)). Express TRPV channel protein [OSM-9](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003889;class=Gene) ([Colbert et al., 1997](http //www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/17/21/8259)). Express a splice variant of the tyramine receptor [SER-2](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http //www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472), [Rex and Komuniecki, 2002](http //www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/118943670/HTMLSTART)). Express alpha subunits of a nicotinic [acetylcholine receptor](http //www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html#sec6), [DEG-3](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=deg-3;class=Locus) and [DES-2](http //www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000955;class=Gene) ([Treinin and Chalfie, 1995](http //www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WSS-4CWYS0K-R&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=6d77922c0d406fdedd8bb40382906482);[ Treinin et al., 1998](httpExpress[ glutamate receptor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_ionotropicglutatmaterecep/ionotropicglutatmaterecep.html) subunit, [GLR-4 ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001615;class=Gene)([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)).

PVM.Description: Posterior ventral microtubule cell, generated postembryonically ([AVM](AVMframeset.html) and PVM are generated at about 9 hours after hatching at 20°C, about 19 hours after egg deposition.). In the L1 stage, PVM extends a process that first grows ventrally along a commissure on the left side of the posterior body and then turns anteriorly when it reaches the ventral nerve cord (VNC). Within VNC the PVM process runs anteriorly on the ventral side adjacent to the cuticle. PVM is an unbranched unipolar neuron.
PVM.Function: PVM is ultrastructurally very similar to the other touch cells, and its differentiation is controlled by the same genetic pathway that controls differentiation of the other five touch receptor neurons. However, PVM does not mediate a locomotory response to gentle touch ([Chalfie and Sulston, 1981](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0012-1606(81)90459-0)) and does not appear to have a critical role in touch sensitivity (for discussion see [Kaplan and Driscoll, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.785); [Goodman, 2006](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_mechanosensation/mechanosensation.html)). It is postulated to be a stretch receptor.
PVM.Location: Lateral. Left side of the posterior half of the body.
PVM.Receptor Expression: Expresses G protein-linked [acetylcholine receptor](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html#sec6), GAR-1 ([Lee et al., 2000](http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/119005436/HTMLSTART)[](http://elegans.swmed.edu/wli/%5Bcgc4388%5D/?%5Cbl%5Be%E9%E8%EA%EB%5D%5Be%E9%E8%EA%EB%5D%5Cb)). Expresses [MEC-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=mec-2;class=Locus) (stomatin-like), [MEC-4](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=mec-4;class=Locus) (degenerin),[ MEC-10](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003174;class=Gene) (degenerin) which comprise part of a mechanosensory transduction channel ([Huang and Chalfie, 1994](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=%5Bcgc1871%5D;class=Paper); [Lai et al., 1996](http://jcb.rupress.org/cgi/reprint/133/5/1071)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/biblio?name=Expr1563&category=&class=Expr_pattern&abstract=%5Bcgc2471%5D#%5Bcgc2471%5D)). Expresses [MEC-9](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003173;class=Gene) which is suggested to provide an extracellular attachment point for the mechanosensory channels in touch cells ([Du et al., 1996](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002379;class=Paper)) and [MEC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003170;class=Gene) which is part of the degenerin/epithelial Na+ channel complex ([Chelur et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005591;class=Paper)). Expresses [UNC-8](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00006748;class=Gene), a DEG/ENaC family member homologous to subunits of a candidate mechanically gated ion channel ([Tavernarakis et al., 1997](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002646;class=Paper)).

PVPL.Description: Interneuron. Differences in connectivity observed between hermaphrodites and males. In hermaphrodites PVP neurites were observed to make branches around the vulva suggesting they may form synapses with egg-laying muscles ([WBG, 1999](http://elegans.swmed.edu/wli/%5Bwbg16.1p24%5D/?%5Cbh%5Bo%BA%F3%F2%F4%F6%F5%F8%5Db%5Be%E9%E8%EA%EB%5Dr%5Bt%FE%5D%5Cb%20target=)). The PVPL/PVPR processes cross over in the pre-anal ganglion and then grow forward on the opposite side of the cord to the nerve ring. The PVPL process invariably crosses in front of the PVPR process. PVPL and PVPR somas are nearly opposite one another in the embryo and early larval stages. However, in the adult, this symmetry and order is lost and cells are situated almost linearly within PAG ([Durbin, 1987](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/durbinv1.2/toc.html)).
PVPL.Function: ** Along with [PVQL](PVQframeset.html), PVPR pioneers the left side ventral cord and this function appears to be a joint action of these two processes. When PVPR precursor is ablated in the embryo, [PVQL](PVQframeset.html) and [AVKR](AVKframeset.html) growth cones migrate towards the right side. ([Durbin, 1987](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/durbinv1.2/toc.html); [Antebi et al., 1997 ](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov:80/books/bv.fcgi?tool=bookshelf&call=bv.View..Sh owSection&searchterm=pvt&rid=ce2.section.727)).

PVPR.Description: Interneuron. Differences in connectivity observed between hermaphrodites and males. In hermaphrodites PVP neurites were observed to make branches around the vulva suggesting they may form synapses with egg-laying muscles ([WBG, 1999](http://elegans.swmed.edu/wli/%5Bwbg16.1p24%5D/?%5Cbh%5Bo%BA%F3%F2%F4%F6%F5%F8%5Db%5Be%E9%E8%EA%EB%5Dr%5Bt%FE%5D%5Cb%20target=)). The PVPL/PVPR processes cross over in the pre-anal ganglion and then grow forward on the opposite side of the cord to the nerve ring. The PVPL process invariably crosses in front of the PVPR process. PVPL and PVPR somas are nearly opposite one another in the embryo and early larval stages. However, in the adult, this symmetry and order is lost and cells are situated almost linearly within PAG ([Durbin, 1987](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/durbinv1.2/toc.html)).
PVPR.Function: ** Along with [PVQL](PVQframeset.html), PVPR pioneers the left side ventral cord and this function appears to be a joint action of these two processes. When PVPR precursor is ablated in the embryo, [PVQL](PVQframeset.html) and [AVKR](AVKframeset.html) growth cones migrate towards the right side. ([Durbin, 1987](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/durbinv1.2/toc.html); [Antebi et al., 1997 ](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov:80/books/bv.fcgi?tool=bookshelf&call=bv.View..Sh owSection&searchterm=pvt&rid=ce2.section.727)).

PVQL.Description: Interneurons, project along ventral cord to ring.
PVQL.Function: ** Along with [PVPR](PVPframeset.html), PVQL pioneers the left hand ventral cord. This function appears to be a joint action of these two processes ([Durbin, 1987](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/durbinv1.2/toc.html)).
PVQL.Receptor Expression: Expresses glutamate receptor subunits, [GLR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001612;class=Gene) and [GLR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001616;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Expresses G protein-coupled serpentine receptor, [SRA-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005032;class=Gene)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=sra-6;class=Locus) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002314;class=Paper)). Expresses the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)). Expresses the serotonin receptor,[ SER-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004776;class=Gene) ([Dernovici et al, 2007](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00029300;class=Paper); [Carnell et al, 2005.](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00028900;class=Paper)). Suggested to express GABA-A/glycine receptor-like protein [GGR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001586;class=Gene) ([Fujiwara et al., 1996](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00015370;class=Paper)).

PVQR.Description: Interneurons, project along ventral cord to ring.
PVQR.Function: ** Along with [PVPR](PVPframeset.html), PVQL pioneers the left hand ventral cord. This function appears to be a joint action of these two processes ([Durbin, 1987](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/durbinv1.2/toc.html)).
PVQR.Receptor Expression: Expresses glutamate receptor subunits, [GLR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001612;class=Gene) and [GLR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001616;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/5/1510)). Expresses G protein-coupled serpentine receptor, [SRA-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00005032;class=Gene)[](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=sra-6;class=Locus) ([Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002314;class=Paper)). Expresses the dopamine receptor [DOP-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001052;class=Gene) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)). Expresses the serotonin receptor,[ SER-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004776;class=Gene) ([Dernovici et al, 2007](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00029300;class=Paper); [Carnell et al, 2005.](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00028900;class=Paper)). Suggested to express GABA-A/glycine receptor-like protein [GGR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001586;class=Gene) ([Fujiwara et al., 1996](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00015370;class=Paper)).

PVT.Description: Interneuron, projects along ventral cord to ring. Hermaphrodites and males exhibit some differences in PVT connectivity.
PVT.Function: Midline neuroblast, secretes [UNC-6](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00006746;class=Gene), serves as a guidepost neuron to guide growing axons from the lumbar ganglia in the posteriormost region of the ventral cord. When PVT is ablated embryonically, these axons follow multiple routes to enter the ventral cord instead of making tight bundles ([Antebi et al., 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov:80/books/bv.fcgi?tool=bookshelf&call=bv.View..ShowSection&searchterm=pvt&rid=ce2.section.727); [Ren et al., 1999](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003467;class=Paper)). Postembryonically, PVT functions to keep the ventral cord fascicles intact. Early larval ablation of PVT induces axons of [AVKL/R](AVKframeset.html), [PVQL/R](PVQframeset.html), [HSNL/R](HSNframeset.html) and [RMEV](RMEframeset.html) to aberrantly cross the ventral midline ([Aurelio et al., 2002](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00005064;class=Paper)).
PVT.Receptor Expression: Expresses a splice variant of the tyramine receptor [ ](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=ser-2;class=Locus) [SER-2](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004777;class=Gene) (variable expression) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)). Expresses the serotonin receptors, [SER-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004776;class=Gene) ([Dernovici et al, 2007](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00029300;class=Paper); [Carnell et al, 2005](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00028900;class=Paper)) and[ SER-4](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004779;class=Gene) (variable expression) ([Tsalik et al., 2003](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WDG-49JPMWH-6&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=62cdf52096d8c8487508967cd90e2472)[](http://elegans.swmed.edu/wli/%5Bcgc6180%5D/?%5Cb%5Bt%FE%5D%5Bs%DF%5D%5Ba%AA%E1%E0%E2%E5%E4%E3%E6%5Dl%5Bi%ED%EC%EE%EF%5Dk%5Cb)).

RIAL.Description: These neurons receive synaptic inputs from AIY and AIZ interneurons and densely innervate head motor neurons SMD and RMD.
RIAL.Function: _ **   - Functions in **thermotaxis:** A mutation that impairs the function RIA neurons or laser ablation of RIA cause athermotactic or cryophilic behavior. However, killing RIA neurons has no effect on chemotaxis ([Iino and Yoshida, 2009](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/29/17/5370.long#ref-21); [Tanizawa et al., 2006](http://genesdev.cshlp.org/content/20/23/3296.full); [Mori and Ohshima 1995](http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v376/n6538/abs/376344a0.html)). In the original two-drive (thermophilic vs cryophilic) model of thermotaxis, RIA is suggested to integrate signals processed in the thermotaxis neural circuit and emit outputs to downstream neurons ([Mori and Ohshima, 1995](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B33); [Tanizawa et al, 2006](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B45)). Multiple transmissions including EAT-4-dependent glutamate from RIA are involved in communicating processed information to downstream neurons, thereby generating ultimate thermotactic outputs ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B33)). Although it is not clear as to which neurons downstream of RIA are main component neurons in the circuit, RIA is heavily connected presynaptically to SMD or RMD head motor neurons that regulate turning behavior, suggesting SMD and RMD control turn frequency and run duration depending on the thermal information transmitted by RIA ([Ohnishi et al, 2011](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B33); [Zariwala et al, 2003](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B49); [White et al, 1986](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B47); [Gray et al, 2005](http://www.nature.com/emboj/journal/v30/n7/full/emboj201113a.html#B16)). - Functions in **locomotion:** Killing RIA slightly decreases reversals during local search and dispersal ([Gray et al., 2005](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long)).
RIAL.Receptor Expression: Expresses the serotonin receptor,[ SER-1](http://wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00004776;class=Gene) ([Dernovici et al, 2007](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00029300;class=Paper); [Carnell et al, 2005](http://wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00028900;class=Paper))

RMED.Function: Suggested to be the pioneers of the nerve ring ([Antebi et al., 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov:80/books/bv.fcgi?tool=bookshelf&call=bv.View..ShowSection&searchterm=rme&rid=ce2.section.718#724)).

RMEL and RMER express glutamate receptor subunit, [GLR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001612;class=Gene) [](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/locus?name=glr-1;class=Locus) ([Hart et al., 1995](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00002309;class=Paper)). SMBDL.Function: _ **   - Functions in **locomotion:** After animals are removed from bacterial food, they initiate a **local search behavior** consisting of reversals and deep omega-shaped turns. This is followed by dispersal ~30 min later as reversal and turns are suppressed. Local search behavior is triggered by [AWC ](AWCframeset.html)olfactory neurons, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) gustatory neurons, and [AIB](AIBframeset.html) interneurons while dispersal is promoted by [ASI](ASIframeset.html) gustatory neurons and [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons ([Gray et al., 2005](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long)). Downstream of AIB and AIY, motor neurons define specific aspects of reversal and turn frequency, amplitude, and directionality. [SMD](SMDframeset.html) motor neurons define the steep amplitude of omega turns, [RIV](RIVframeset.html) motor neurons specify the ventral bias of turns that follow a reversal, and SMB motor neurons set the amplitude of sinusoidal movement.
SMBDL.Lineage: AB alpapapapp, AB arappapapp, AB alpapappp, AB arappappp

Local search behavior is triggered by [AWC ](AWCframeset.html)olfactory neurons, [ASK](ASKframeset.html) gustatory neurons, and [AIB](AIBframeset.html) interneurons while dispersal is promoted by [ASI](ASIframeset.html) gustatory neurons and [AIY](AIYframeset.html) interneurons ([Gray et al., 2005](http://www.pnas.org/content/102/9/3184.long)). SMD motor neurons define the steep amplitude of omega turns, [RIV](RIVframeset.html) motor neurons specify the ventral bias of turns that follow a reversal, and [SMB](SMDframeset.html) motor neurons set the amplitude of sinusoidal movement.
SMDDL.Lineage: AB plpapaaaa, AB prpapaaaa, AB alppappaa, AB arappppaa
