URXL.Description: Nonciliated endings in head, associated with CEPD in embryo. Like [AQR](AQRframeset.html) and [PQR](PQRframeset.html), URX are directly exposed to the pseudocoelomic fluid and are proposed to monitor the contents of this fluid.
URXL.Function_: **    - Function in [aerotaxis](http://www.wormatlas.org/hermaphrodite/nervous/Neuroframeset.html#Oxygensensation246): When placed in an O2 gradient, _C. elegans_ shows a strong behavioral preference for ~5-10% (intermediate) O2 levels and avoids both hypoxia (<7%) and hyperoxia (21%). Animals navigate the O2 gradients by O2-induced changes in locomotion speed, reversal and turning behavior&nbsp_place_holder; ([Cheung et al., 2005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2005.04.017); [Gray et al., 2004](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature02714)). This preference for intermediate O2 levels ([Gray et al., 2004](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature02714)), may work to allow oxidative metabolism but avoid oxidative stress ([Lee and Atkinson, 1977](http://books.google.com/books/about/Physiology_of_nematodes.html?id=JAmMAAAAIAAJ)). The intermediate O2 preference also promotes aggregation behavior, possibly since aggregating _C. elegans_ locally deplete O2 to preferred levels ([Gray et al., 2004](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature02714); [Rogers et al., 2006](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2006.03.023)). The rise in O2 levels detected by animals leaving a group induces reversal (backing) and turning. Conversely, the fall in O2 encountered when entering a group suppresses reversal, turning, and rapid locomotion, allowing the animal to stay with the group. Soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC, e.g. [GCY-35](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001555) and [GCY-36](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001556))-expressing oxygen-sensing neurons (URX, [AQR](AQRframeset.html), [PQR](PQRframeset.html), [SDQ](SDQframeset.html), [BDU](BDUframeset.html), [ALN](ALNframeset.html), and [PLN](PLNframeset.html)) mediate the avoidance of high O2 levels ([Zimmer et al, 2009](http://dx.crossref.org/10.1016%2Fj.neuron.2009.02.013)). URX appears to be the most important member of this group, since its activity is uniquely important for aggregation ([Coates and de Bono, 2002](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature01170)),&nbsp_place_holder;while for aerotactic behavior in an O2 gradient, URX is redundant with other sGC-expressing neurons ([Chang et al., 2006](http://www.plosbiology.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.0040274)). The locations of URX in the head and [PQR](PQRframeset.html) in the tail facilitate high O2 avoidance by the animal accelerating forward without changing direction of movement when its tail/[PQR](PQRframeset.html) encounters high O2 and by reversal and turning when its head/URX encounters high O2 ([Busch et al., 2012](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nn.3061)). Two post-synaptic targets of URX, [AUA](AUAframeset.html) and [RMG](RMGframeset.html), seem to be involved in this O2-induced behavioral response. The strength of the O2 response is regulated by food, genotype, and an animal's prior O2 exposure. The lab standard wild-type _C. elegans_ strain (N2) with high activity (due to a gain-of-function mutation) of the neuropeptide receptor [NPR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003807) (215V) is indifferent to high O2 when food is present, whereas _C. elegans_ isolates with low activity of [NPR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003807)_ _(215F) avoid high O2 in the presence of food, and therefore, aggregate ([Gray et al., 2004](http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature02714); [Cheung et al., 2005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2005.04.017); [Rogers et al., 2006](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2006.03.023)). Since all strains avoid high O2 when food is absent, [NPR-1 ](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003807)may be an internal food sensor important for food-related regulation of aggregation (i.e., regulation of social behavior on food) ([Chang et al., 2006](http://www .plosbiology.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.0040274)). Cultivation conditions also regulate O2 preference: animals cultivated in hypoxia migrate to lower O2 levels, and avoid high O2 regardless of food or[ NPR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003807)_ _genotype ([Cheung et al., 2005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2005.04.017); [Chang and Bargmann, 2008](http://www.pnas.org/content/105/20/7321.long)). The sensory neurons [ASH](ASHframeset.html), [ADL](ADLframeset.html), and [ADF](ADFframeset.html) also promote avoidance of high O2 levels (through function of TRP-related channel subunits [OCR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003839) and [OSM-9](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003889) and the transmembrane protein [ODR-4](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003851) in nociceptive [ASH](ASHframeset.html) and [ADL](ADLframeset.html), and serotonin production by [ADF](ADFframeset.html)), but these cells are not needed after animals are cultivated in hypoxia ([Chang et al., 2006](http://www.plosbiology .org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pbio.0040274); [Chang and Bargmann; 2008](http://www.pnas.org/content/105/20/7321.long); [Rogers et al., 2006](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2006.03.023)).
URXL.Innexin expression: _**   None yet reported, although described to have gap junctions in adult animals ([MoW](http://www.wormatlas.org/ver1/MoW_built0.92/toc.html))
URXL.Neurotransmitter/ Neuropeptide: _**   - [FLP-8](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001451); FMRFamide-like peptide - [FLP-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001453); FMRFamide-like peptide - [FLP-11](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001454); FMRFamide-like peptide - [FLP-19](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001462); FMRFamide-like peptide ([Li and Kim, 2008](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_neuropeptides/neuropeptides.html))
URXL.Receptor expression: _**    - [GCY-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001528); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [GCY-25](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001549); transmembrane receptor guanylate cyclase - [GCY-32](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001552); soluble guanylate cyclase - [GCY-34](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001554); soluble guanylate cyclase - [GCY-35](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001555); soluble guanylate cyclase - [GCY-36](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001556); soluble guanylate cyclase - [GCY-37](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001557); soluble guanylate cyclase -[ NPR-1](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00003807); receptor for [_flp-18_](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001461)- and [_flp-21_](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00001464)-encoded peptides - [SRA-10](http://www.wormbase.org/species/c_elegans/gene/WBGene00005036); G protein-coupled seven transmembrane receptor ([Wormbase](http://www.wormbase.org); [Cheung et al., 2004](http://www.cell.com/current-biology/retrieve/pii/S0960982204003896); [Troemel et al., 1995](http://www.cell.com/retrieve/pii/0092867495901620))
URXL.Type: Sensory neuron (oxygen sensor), also ring interneuron

VC1.Description: Hermaphrodite specific ventral cord motor neurons. The neurons are born in L1, and begin to send out processes in late L3. These processes branch in the region of the vulva during L4. VC4 and VC5 have short ventral cord processes, but send branched processes dorsally along the vulval hypodermis on each side of the vulval slit. VC1-3 and VC6 send less branched processes to vulval regions but have longer processes in the ventral cord (in R side fascicle). The dorsal branches of VC axons innervate vm2 vulval muscles. These neurons, except VC4 and VC5, also innervate ventral body muscles. The generation of VC neurons from the 6 Pn.a neuroblast lineages (P3.a-P8.a) is dependent on a HOM-C gene,_ [lin-39](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?n ame=WBGene00003024;class=Gene)_. In the absence of _[lin-39](http://www.wormba se.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00003024;class=Gene),_ these neurons undergo programmed cell death ([Ruvkun, 1997)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fc gi?call=bv.View..ShowSection&rid=ce2.section.699). The formation of the complex arborizations made by VC neuron branches at the level of the vulva depend on the presence of the vulval cells and the somatic gonad but not on the interactions of VC's with target muscles or [HSN](HSNframeset.html) neurons ([Li and Chalfie, 1990](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00001300;class=Paper); [Colavita and Tessier-Lavigne, 2003](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00006123;class=Paper)) For a more detailed anatomical description of VC neurons also refer to [Reproductive System-Egg-laying apparatus](../../hermaphrodite/egglaying apparatus/Eggframeset.html).
VC1.Function: [Acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html) released from the VC neurons inhibits egg-laying behavior. This may be caused by inhibition of presynaptic neurotransmitter release by [HSN](HSNframeset.html) neurons following the activation of the G-protein- coupled acetylcholine receptor 2 ([GAR-2](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001518;class=Gene)) signaling ([Bany et al., 2003](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/23/22/8060)). VC4 and VC5 can also induce the active phase of egg-laying by releasing serotonin ([Waggoner et al., 1998](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00003151;class=Paper)).
VC1.Lineage: P3 aap, P4 aap, P5 aap, P6 aap, P7 aap, P8 aap
VC1.Neurotransmitter: **[Serotonin](http(only VC4 and VC5) [Rand and Nonet, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=ce2.table.5914). Express VMaT, [CAT-1](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00000295;class=Gene) ([Duerr et al., 1999](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/19/1/72)). [Acetylcholine](http://www.wormbook.org/chapters/www_acetylcholine/acetylcholine.html). ([Rand and Nonet, 1997](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=ce2.table.5914)). Express ChAT and VAChT ([Duerr et al., 2001](http://www.wormbase.org/db/misc/paper?name=WBPaper00004691;class=Paper); [Lickteig et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/full/21/6/2001)).
VC1.Receptor Expression: Express glutamate receptor subunit, [GLR-5](http://www.wormbase.org/db/gene/gene?name=WBGene00001616;class=Gene) ([Brockie et al., 2001](http://www.jneurosci.org/content/21/5/1510.full)).
